title: Cripps' mission
text: Both the major parties, the Congress and the League rejected his proposals and the mission proved a failure.

title: Cripps' mission
text: Cripps had designed the proposals himself, but they were too radical for both Churchill and the Indians; no middle way was found.

title: Cripps' mission
text: Congress moved towards the Quit India movement whereby it refused to cooperate in the war effort, while the British imprisoned practically the entire Congress leadership for the duration of the war.

title: Cripps' mission
text: Jinnah was pleased to see that the right to opt out of a future Union was included.

title: Mabel Bassett
text: Mabel Luella Bourne Bassett (August 16, 1876 – 1953) was a Democratic Oklahoma politician who served as the state's Commissioner of Charities and Corrections from 1923 until 1947.

title: Mabel Bassett
text: Born in Chicago, Bassett lived in St. Louis before moving to Sapulpa, Oklahoma in 1902.

title: Mabel Bassett
text: Prior to seeking political office, she founded the Creek County Humane Society, one of the first humane societies in Oklahoma.

title: Mabel Bassett
text: Once in office, Bassett was responsible for establishing a women's unit of the Oklahoma State Penitentiary and transferring African-American juvenile delinquents from the state penitentiary to a training school in Boley.

title: Mabel Bassett
text: Bassett also campaigned for a seat in the U.S. House of Representatives in 1932; however, she lost to fellow Democrat Will Rogers.

title: Mabel Bassett
text: Buck Cook replaced Bassett as Commissioner of Charities and Corrections in 1947, at which point Bassett retired from politics.

title: Mabel Bassett
text: Upon her death in 1953, she lay in state in the Oklahoma State Capitol.

title: 13th Oklahoma Legislature
text: The Thirteenth Oklahoma Legislature was a meeting of the legislative branch of the government of Oklahoma, composed of the Oklahoma Senate and the Oklahoma House of Representatives.

title: 13th Oklahoma Legislature
text: The state legislature met in Oklahoma City, in regular session from January 6 to April 11, 1931, during the term of Governor William H. Murray.

title: 13th Oklahoma Legislature
text: Murray, a former House speaker, helped Wilburton editor Carlton Weaver become Speaker; both were members of the constitutional convention.

title: 13th Oklahoma Legislature
text: Despite his political maneuvering, the governor found opposition to many of his proposals.

title: 13th Oklahoma Legislature
text: The session marked the first instance that redistricting was done outside of constitutional requirements.

title: 15th Oklahoma Legislature
text: The Fifteenth Oklahoma Legislature was a meeting of the legislative branch of the government of Oklahoma, composed of the Oklahoma Senate and the Oklahoma House of Representatives.

title: 15th Oklahoma Legislature
text: The state legislature met from January 8 to April 30, 1935, during the term of Governor E.W. Marland.

title: 15th Oklahoma Legislature
text: Marland influenced the selection of Leon C. Phillips for Speaker of the Oklahoma House of Representatives.

title: 15th Oklahoma Legislature
text: Phillips had been an opponent of Governor William H. Murray's proposals.

title: 15th Oklahoma Legislature
text: Phillips also opposed many of Marland's proposals.

title: Cowboy Pink Williams
text: Cowboy Pink Williams, born Simeon Pinckney Williams (April 9, 1892 – April 1, 1976), was an Oklahoma politician who was the seventh Lieutenant Governor of Oklahoma from 1955 to 1959 and Oklahoma State Treasurer from 1963 to 1967.

title: Kings County Museum (Hampton, New Brunswick)
text: The Kings County Museum is located in Hampton, New Brunswick and is run by the Kings County Historical and Archival Society, housed in the Centennial Building, with displays also in the old Kings County gaol next door.

title: Kings County Museum (Hampton, New Brunswick)
text: Late in 1966, with the approach of the Centennial Year, an agreement was made between the Kings County Historical Society, the Municipality of Kings County, and the New Brunswick Centennial Administration to have space for a Museum in the new County Centennial Building in Hampton.

title: Kings County Museum (Hampton, New Brunswick)
text: The official opening of the Kings County Museum was on June 1, 1968.

title: Kings County Museum (Hampton, New Brunswick)
text: The museum is home to many artifacts and historical items from Kings County's past, and the main exhibit room is changed to display new artifacts every two (almost consistent) years.

title: Kings County Museum (Hampton, New Brunswick)
text: Being open for 50+ years, the museum has accumulated an overwhelming amount of artifacts – all with a unique backgrounds involving Kings County.

title: Kings County Museum (Hampton, New Brunswick)
text: The museum is open in the summertime and certain hours in the wintertime to the public for tours of the exhibit and the old gaol.

title: Kings County Museum (Hampton, New Brunswick)
text: Guests can explore the many different books and stories about Kings County history that are for sale, and the museum also offers genealogy research.

title: Kings County Museum (Hampton, New Brunswick)
text: It holds documentations of many place histories in Kings County, family genealogies and more.

title: Fernbank Museum of Natural History
text: Fernbank Museum of Natural History, in Atlanta, is a museum that presents exhibitions and programming about natural history that are meant to entertain as well as educate the public.

title: Fernbank Museum of Natural History
text: Its mission is to encourage a greater appreciation of the planet and its people.

title: Fernbank Museum of Natural History
text: Fernbank Museum has a number of permanent exhibitions and regularly hosts temporary exhibitions in its expansive facility, designed by Graham Gund Architects.

title: Fernbank Museum of Natural History
text: "Giants of the Mesozoic", on display in the atrium of Fernbank Museum, features a 123 ft long Argentinosaurus (the largest dinosaur ever classified) as well as a Giganotosaurus.

title: Fernbank Museum of Natural History
text: The permanent exhibition, "A Walk Through Time in Georgia", tells the twofold story of Georgia's natural history and the development of the planet.

title: Fernbank Museum of Natural History
text: Fernbank Museum has won several national and international awards for one of its newest permanent exhibitions, Fernbank NatureQuest, an immersive, interactive exhibition for children that was designed and produced by Thinkwell Group.

title: Fernbank Museum of Natural History
text: The awards NatureQuest has won include the 2012 Thea Award for Outstanding Achievement for a Museum Exhibit and the 2011 Bronze Award for Best Museum Environment from Event Design.

title: Fernbank Museum of Natural History
text: The nearby Fernbank Science Center is a separate organization operated by the DeKalb County Board of Education and is not affiliated with Fernbank Museum of Natural History (Fernbank, Inc.).

title: Deadwood, South Dakota
text: Deadwood (Lakota: "Owáyasuta"; "To approve or confirm things") is a city in South Dakota, United States, and the county seat of Lawrence County.

title: Deadwood, South Dakota
text: It is named after the dead trees found in its gulch.

title: Deadwood, South Dakota
text: The population was 1,270 according to the 2010 census.

title: Deadwood, South Dakota
text: The entire city is a National Historic Landmark District, for its well-preserved Gold Rush-era architecture.

title: Yarmouth Runic Stone
text: The Yarmouth Runic Stone, also known as the Fletcher Stone, is a slab of quartzite that first came to the attention of the public in the early 19th Century.

title: Yarmouth Runic Stone
text: The stone appears to have an inscription carved into it, which some investigators, notably Henry Phillips, Jr., have interpreted as Norse runes.

title: Yarmouth Runic Stone
text: This has led to speculation that the Yarmouth, Nova Scotia area, in Canada, was visited by Viking explorers sometime around 1000 C.E.

title: Yarmouth Runic Stone
text: Many other theories have been put forward, including the possibility of a hoax or the inscription being a product of natural forces.

title: Yarmouth Runic Stone
text: The Stone is currently on display at the Yarmouth County Museum.

title: Goa State Museum
text: Goa State Museum, also known as the State Archaeology Museum, Panaji, is a museum in Goa, India.

title: Goa State Museum
text: Established in 1977, it contains departments including Ancient History and Archaeology, Art and Craft, and Geology.

title: Goa State Museum
text: The museum, as of 2008, had about 8,000 artifacts on display, including stone sculptures, wooden objects, carvings, bronzes, paintings, manuscripts, rare coins, and anthropological objects.

title: Goa State Museum
text: The museum was currently located at the EDC Complex in Patto, Panaji; earlier it was housed at St. Inez, Panjim.

title: Goa State Museum
text: As of May 2018, the Museum has been closed for visitors since the artefacts are shifted to the Adil Shah's Palace (Old Secretariat) in Panaji.

title: Goa State Museum
text: The Museum's premises at the EDC Complex in Patto, Panaji shall be demolished to make way for a new Museum building.

title: National Railway Museum Shildon
text: National Railway Museum Shildon, also known as Locomotion: the National Railway Museum at Shildon or Shildon Locomotion Museum is a railway museum in Shildon, County Durham, England.

title: National Railway Museum Shildon
text: The museum is a branch of the National Railway Museum (NRM), which is part of the Science Museum Group.

title: National Railway Museum Shildon
text: Shildon acts as an annex, with important exhibits on display in the NRM's headquarters at York, though major exhibits are regularly rotated.

title: Stele Forest
text: The Stele Forest, or Beilin Museum (碑林; pinyin: Bēilín), is a museum for steles and stone sculptures in Xi'an, China.

title: Stele Forest
text: The museum, which is housed in a former Confucian Temple, has housed a growing collection of Steles since 1087.

title: Stele Forest
text: By 1944 it was the principal museum for Shaanxi province.

title: Stele Forest
text: Due to the large number of steles, it was officially renamed the Forest of Stone Steles in 1992.

title: Stele Forest
text: Altogether, there are 3,000 steles in the museum, which is divided into seven exhibitions halls, which mainly display works of calligraphy, painting and historical records.

title: Tankavaara
text: Tankavaara is a village and a tourist attraction in the municipality of Sodankylä in Lapland, Finland.

title: Tankavaara
text: It is located by the E75 highway 90 kilometres north of Sodankylä and 30 kilometers south of the Saariselkä ski resort.

title: Tankavaara
text: Tankavaara is famous of its gold prospecting that started in the 1930s.

title: Tankavaara
text: Since the 1970s, the village has been a tourist attraction including hotel, restaurants and the Gold Prospector Museum.

title: Tankavaara
text: The International Gold Museum presents the history of Finnish gold, as well as the history of the world's major gold rushes.

title: Tankavaara
text: A display called Golden world, tells the story of gold in more than 20 countries.

title: Tankavaara
text: The outdoor museum is housed within several historic buildings and the courtyard is decorated with a large bronze statue of a gold prospector, by the artist professor Ensio Seppänen.

title: Tankavaara
text: The museum's stone and mineral collection has more than 2500 samples on display from around the world.

title: Thoen Stone
text: The Thoen Stone is a sandstone slab dated 1834 that was discovered in the Black Hills of South Dakota by Louis Thoen in 1887.

title: Thoen Stone
text: The discovery of the stone called into question the first discovery of gold and the history of gold mining in the Black Hills; it would mean that gold was discovered in the Black Hills 40 years before the Custer Expedition of 1874 and the subsequent Black Hills Gold Rush.

title: Thoen Stone
text: It is currently on display at the Adams Museum & House in Deadwood, South Dakota.

title: Clay County Historical Museum
text: The Clay County Historical Society Museum is located in Green Cove Springs, Clay County, Florida.

title: Clay County Historical Museum
text: It is located in a former trail depot.

title: Clay County Historical Museum
text: Exhibits include railroad memorabilia, a country kitchen display and a country store display.

title: Clay County Historical Museum
text: It is operated by the Clay County Historical Society.

title: Clay County Historical Museum
text: The museum is located at 915 Walnut Street in the Historical Triangle which also includes the 1896 county jail and 1890 courthouse at Walnut Street and Ferris Street (Hwy 16).

title: Mercy Hospital and Medical Center
text: Mercy Hospital and Medical Center is a 292 bed general medical and surgical Catholic teaching hospital in Chicago, Illinois.

title: Mercy Hospital and Medical Center
text: Established in 1852, The hospital was the first chartered hospital in Chicago.

title: Mercy Hospital and Medical Center
text: In 1859, Mercy Hospital became the first Catholic hospital to affiliate with a medical school—Lind Medical School—and the first to require a graded curriculum.

title: Mercy Hospital and Medical Center
text: Today, Mercy Hospital and Medical Center is part of a nationwide network of Mercy Healthcare facilities.

title: Mercy Hospital and Medical Center
text: Mercy also is the hospital used by the Daley family: all of their children were born there.

title: Mercy Hospital and Medical Center
text: Mercy sold a plot of land to the north of their hospital for 60 million dollars in 2008.

title: Mercy Hospital and Medical Center
text: It is also the main women's cancer center in Illinois.

title: Mercy Hospital and Medical Center
text: It accepted patients from Michael Reese Hospital and Medical Center and absorbed the ambulance routes when the hospital closed in 2008.

title: Mercy Hospital and Medical Center
text: Mercy follows Catholic teaching but does give birth control to rape patients.

title: Brad Wenstrup
text: Brad Robert Wenstrup (born June 17, 1958) is an American politician, Army Reserve officer, and Doctor of Podiatric Medicine, who has been the U.S. Representative for Ohio 's 2 congressional district since 2013.

title: Brad Wenstrup
text: A Republican, he defeated U.S. Representative Jean Schmidt in the 2012 Republican primary election and Democrat William R. Smith in the 2012 general election.

title: Brad Wenstrup
text: Wenstrup is a colonel in the U.S. Army Reserve and an Iraq War veteran.

title: Brad Wenstrup
text: After the shooting of Congressman Steve Scalise on the morning of June 14, 2017, Wenstrup attended to the wounded congressman until he was transported to MedStar Washington Hospital Center.

title: Baylor College of Medicine
text: Baylor College of Medicine (BCM), located in the Texas Medical Center in Houston, Texas, US, is a health sciences university.

title: Baylor College of Medicine
text: It includes a medical school, Baylor College of Medicine; the Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences; the School of Allied Health Sciences; and the National School of Tropical Medicine.

title: Baylor College of Medicine
text: The school, located in the middle of the world's largest medical center (Texas Medical Center), is part owner of Baylor St. Luke's Medical Center, part of the CHI St. Luke's Health system, and has hospital affiliations with: Harris Health System, Texas Children's Hospital, The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center, Memorial Hermann - The Institute for Rehabilitation and Research, Menninger Clinic, the Michael E. DeBakey Veterans Affairs Medical Center and Children's Hospital of San Antonio.

title: Adventist Medical Center Manila
text: The Adventist Medical Center Manila, (formerly the Manila Adventist Medical Center; Manila Sanitarium and Hospital), is an acute care, tertiary, non-stock, non-profit, and self-supporting private hospital that is located within Pasay in Metro Manila, Philippines.

title: Adventist Medical Center Manila
text: It was established on 1929 by a missionary doctor - Horace Hall.

title: Adventist Medical Center Manila
text: It is one of the two constituents, the other being an educational institution, that formed the Adventist Medical Center Manila.

title: Adventist Medical Center Manila
text: The hospital is part of a chain of more than 500 health care institutions worldwide operated by the Seventh-day Adventist Church.

title: Adventist Medical Center Manila
text: It is licensed by the Center for Health Development of the Philippine Department of Health, accredited by Medicare, the Philippine Hospital Association and the American Hospital Association.

title: Banner University Medical Center Tucson
text: Banner - University Medical Center Tucson (BUMCT), formerly University Medical Center and the University of Arizona Medical Center, is a private, non-profit, 487-bed acute-care hospital located on the campus of the University of Arizona in Tucson, Arizona.

title: Banner University Medical Center Tucson
text: BUMCT is part of the University of Arizona Health Sciences (UAHS) center campus which includes the university's Colleges of Medicine, Nursing, Pharmacy and Public Health.

title: Banner University Medical Center Tucson
text: It is Southern Arizona's only Level I trauma center for both adult and pediatric patients.

title: Banner University Medical Center Tucson
text: BUMCT is one of two University of Arizona affiliated academic medical centers in Tucson with Banner - University Medical Center South (formerly Kino Community Hospital, University Physicians Healthcare Hospital, and University of Arizona Medical Center - South Campus) being the other such institution.

title: Banner University Medical Center Tucson
text: The area's only dedicated Children's hospital, Banner Children's at Diamond Children's Medical Center, is located within and adjacent to BUMCT.

title: Children's National Medical Center
text: Children’s National Medical Center (formerly DC Children’s Hospital) is ranked among the top 10 children’s hospitals in the country by "U.S. News & World Report."

title: Children's National Medical Center
text: Located just north of the McMillan Reservoir and Howard University, it shares grounds with Washington Hospital Center, National Rehabilitation Hospital, and the DC Veterans Affairs Medical Center.

title: Children's National Medical Center
text: Kurt Newman, M.D., has served as the president and chief executive officer of Children’s National since 2011.

title: Children's National Medical Center
text: Children's National is a not-for-profit institution that performs more than 450,000 visits each year.

title: Children's National Medical Center
text: Featuring 303 beds and a Level IV NICU, Children's National is the regional referral center for pediatric emergency, trauma, cancer, cardiac and critical care as well as neonatology, orthopaedic surgery, neurology and neurosurgery.

title: NewYork–Presbyterian Hospital
text: The NewYork–Presbyterian Hospital is a nonprofit university hospital in New York City affiliated with two Ivy League medical schools: Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons and Weill Cornell Medical College.

title: NewYork–Presbyterian Hospital
text: It is composed of two distinct medical centers, Columbia University Medical Center and Weill Cornell Medical Center.

title: NewYork–Presbyterian Hospital
text: s of 2017 , the hospital is ranked as the 8th best hospital in the United States and 1st in the New York City metropolitan area by "U.S. News & World Report".

title: NewYork–Presbyterian Hospital
text: The hospital has 2,478 beds in total, and is one of the largest hospitals in the United States.

title: NewYork–Presbyterian Hospital
text: New York–Presbyterian Hospital is among the largest hospitals and largest private employers in New York City, and one of the world's busiest.

title: MedStar Georgetown University Hospital
text: MedStar Georgetown University Hospital is one of the national capital area's oldest academic teaching hospitals.

title: MedStar Georgetown University Hospital
text: It is a not-for-profit, acute care teaching and research facility located in the Georgetown neighborhood of the Northwest Quadrant of Washington, D.C.

title: MedStar Georgetown University Hospital
text: MedStar Georgetown is co-located with the Georgetown University Medical Center and is affiliated with the Georgetown University School of Medicine.

title: MedStar Georgetown University Hospital
text: Its clinical services represent one of the largest, most geographically diverse, and fully integrated healthcare and delivery networks in the area.

title: MedStar Georgetown University Hospital
text: MedStar Georgetown is home to the internationally known Lombardi Comprehensive Cancer Center, as well as centers of excellence in the neurology, neurosurgery, psychiatry, gastroenterology, transplant and vascular surgery.

title: MedStar Georgetown University Hospital
text: Originally named Georgetown University Hospital, it became part of the MedStar Health network in 2000.

title: MedStar Washington Hospital Center
text: MedStar Washington Hospital Center is the largest private hospital in Washington, D.C. A member of MedStar Health, the not-for-profit Hospital Center is licensed for 926 beds.

title: MedStar Washington Hospital Center
text: Health services in primary, secondary and tertiary care are offered to adult and neonatal patients.

title: MedStar Washington Hospital Center
text: It also serves as a teaching hospital for Georgetown University School of Medicine.

title: Capitol University Medical City
text: Capitol University Medical Center (formerly Cagayan Capitol General Hospital Foundation Incorporated) in Cagayan de Oro, Philippines, is the Base Hospital for the Capitol University.

title: Capitol University Medical City
text: This private hospital is one of the largest and leading private medical facilities in Mindanao.

title: Capitol University Medical City
text: In 2009,the new and expanded CUMC opened its doors to hundreds offering sects to affiliate in this bustling hospital.

title: Capitol University Medical City
text: Capitol University Medical Center stands as the base training of Capitol University's College of Nursing and College of Midwifery students in this medical center.

title: Claud Andrew Montagu Douglas Scott
text: Brigadier Claud Andrew Montagu Douglas Scott, DSO (13 July 1906 – 24 January 1971) was the first child and only son born to Lieutenant Colonel Lord Herbert Andrew Montagu Douglas Scott and Marie Josephine Edwards.

title: Claud Andrew Montagu Douglas Scott
text: He was a grandson of Sir William Henry Walter Montagu Douglas Scott, 6th Duke of Buccleuch & 8th Duke of Queensberry and Lady Louisa Jane Hamilton, and a paternal first cousin to Lady Alice, Duchess of Gloucester, later known as Princess Alice, Duchess of Gloucester.

title: Claud Andrew Montagu Douglas Scott
text: He was a maternal first cousin once removed to Prince William of Gloucester and Prince Richard, Duke of Gloucester, a paternal great-uncle to Sarah, Duchess of York, and a maternal second great-uncle to Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie of York.

title: Prince George Cougars
text: The Prince George Cougars are a Canadian major junior ice hockey team currently members of the B.C. Division of the Western Conference in the Western Hockey League (WHL).

title: Prince George Cougars
text: The team is based in Prince George, British Columbia, and plays its home games at the CN Centre, formally known as the Prince George Multiplex.

title: Prince George Cougars
text: The Cougars were founded in 1971 as the Victoria Cougars, but later moved to Prince George in 1994.

title: Prince George Cougars
text: On March 19, 2014, after months of rumours, a team of local investors led by Greg Pocock, along with NHLers Dan Hamhuis and Eric Brewer, agreed in principle to purchase the Prince George Cougars.

title: Prince George Cougars
text: The deal was approved by the WHL Board of Governors on April 30 the same year.

title: Gloucester House
text: Gloucester House or Gloucester Lodge is a former royal residence on the esplanade in the seaside resort of Weymouth on the south coast of England.

title: Gloucester House
text: It was the summer residence of Prince William Henry Duke of Gloucester and Edinburgh (1743–1805), fourth son of Frederick, Prince of Wales, and brother of King George III.

title: Gloucester House
text: During his recovery from porphyria in 1789, George III spent some time convalescing there.

title: Gloucester House
text: The king occupied the right-hand part of the building, and would have had use of the garden, situated where the later, left-side wing now stands.

title: Gloucester House
text: His doctors encouraged him to visit the resort to benefit from the sea air and salt water.

title: Gloucester House
text: The patronage of the king was important in drawing fashionable society to the south coast town.

title: Prince George of Denmark
text: Prince George of Denmark and Norway, Duke of Cumberland (Danish: "Jørgen" ; 2 April 165328 October 1708), was the husband of Queen Anne, who reigned over Great Britain from 1702.

title: Henry Scott, 3rd Duke of Buccleuch
text: Henry Scott, 3rd Duke of Buccleuch and 5th Duke of Queensberry KG KT FRSE (2 September 1746 – 11 January 1812) was a Scottish nobleman and long-time friend of the notable Sir Walter Scott.

title: Henry Scott, 3rd Duke of Buccleuch
text: He is the paternal 3rd great-grandfather of Princess Alice, Duchess of Gloucester, and the maternal 4th great-grandfather of Prince William of Gloucester and Prince Richard, Duke of Gloucester.

title: Louisa Hamilton, Duchess of Abercorn
text: Louisa Jane Hamilton, Duchess of Abercorn, VA (née Lady Louisa Jane Russell) (8 July 1812 – 31 March 1905) was the wife of James Hamilton, 1st Duke of Abercorn, and the daughter of John Russell, 6th Duke of Bedford, by his second wife, Lady Georgiana Gordon.

title: Louisa Hamilton, Duchess of Abercorn
text: She was the mother of Louisa Montagu Douglas Scott, Duchess of Buccleuch, and therefore the paternal great grandmother of Princess Alice, Duchess of Gloucester, and the maternal 2nd great-grandmother of Prince William of Gloucester and Prince Richard, Duke of Gloucester.

title: Louisa Hamilton, Duchess of Abercorn
text: She was also the mother of James Hamilton, 2nd Duke of Abercorn, and therefore the paternal great-grandmother of Cynthia Spencer, Countess Spencer, and the paternal 3rd great-grandmother of Diana, Princess of Wales, and the maternal 4th great-grandmother of Prince William, Duke of Cambridge, and Prince Harry.

title: Louisa Hamilton, Duchess of Abercorn
text: Through her daughter Lady Louisa Hamilton she also is the maternal 3rd great-grandmother of Sarah, Duchess of York.

title: Princess Alice, Duchess of Gloucester
text: Princess Alice, Duchess of Gloucester, {'1': ", '2': ", '3': ", '4': "} (Alice Christabel; née Montagu Douglas Scott ; 25 December 1901 – 29 October 2004) was the wife of Prince Henry, Duke of Gloucester, the third son of George V and Mary of Teck.

title: Princess Alice, Duchess of Gloucester
text: She was the mother of the present Duke of Gloucester, and of Prince William of Gloucester, who died aged 30.

title: Prince William, Duke of Gloucester
text: Prince William, Duke of Gloucester (24 July 1689 – 30 July 1700 ) was the son of Princess Anne, later Queen of England, Ireland and Scotland from 1702, and her husband, Prince George, Duke of Cumberland.

title: Prince William, Duke of Gloucester
text: He was their only child to survive infancy.

title: Prince William, Duke of Gloucester
text: Styled Duke of Gloucester, he was viewed by contemporaries as a Protestant champion because his birth seemed to cement the Protestant succession established in the "Glorious Revolution" that had deposed his Catholic grandfather James II the previous year.

title: Prince Georg of Hanover
text: Prince Georg of Hanover ("Georg Paul Christian Prinz von Hannover"), Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg (born 9 December 1949 at Schloss Salem in Salem, Baden-Württemberg, Germany).

title: Prince Georg of Hanover
text: Georg is the second eldest son of Prince George William of Hanover and his wife Princess Sophie of Greece and Denmark, an elder sister of Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh.

title: Prince Georg of Hanover
text: Georg is a male-line descendant of George III of the United Kingdom and Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz and a descendant of Albert, Prince Consort and Victoria of the United Kingdom through their daughters Victoria, Princess Royal and Princess Alice of the United Kingdom.

title: Prince Georg of Hanover
text: He is a first cousin of Charles, Prince of Wales and nephew of Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh and Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom.

title: Dorothy Clement
text: Dorothy Clement (c. 1715 – c. 1739) was the mistress of Edward Walpole and mother of his four children, including Maria Walpole, who became Duchess of Gloucester and Edinburgh upon her marriage to Prince William Henry, Duke of Gloucester and Edinburgh.

title: Dorothy Clement
text: Daughter of a Darlington postmaster, she is an ancestor of Prince William, Duke of Cambridge.

title: Takhini River
text: The Takhini River is a watercourse in Yukon, Canada.

title: Takhini River
text: The river is located just north of Whitehorse, Yukon, and flows from west to east, meeting the Yukon River at a point between Whitehorse and Lake Laberge.

title: Takhini River
text: During the winter, the river freezes and serves as part of the route of the Yukon Quest sled dog race.

title: Yukon International Storytelling Festival
text: The Yukon International Storytelling Festival was held every Summer in Whitehorse, Yukon, generally in an outdoor setting.

title: Yukon International Storytelling Festival
text: Cofounders of the storytelling festival were storytellers Louise Profeit-Leblanc and Anne Taylor.

title: Yukon International Storytelling Festival
text: Profeit-Leblanc, from the Northern Tutchone Nation, was the niece of Angela Sidney {'1': ", '2': ", '3': ", '4': "} (1902 – 1991), one the Yukon's last Tagish.

title: Yukon International Storytelling Festival
text: Sidney had devoted her life to preserving the stories of the Tagish of Southern Yukon, Profeit-Leblanc and Taylor were motivated to found a more local venue for sharing Yukon stories when they realized that Sidney had had to travel in 1984 Toronto Festival of Storytelling to disseminate her peoples' stories to a world audience.

title: Yukon International Storytelling Festival
text: In 1987 interested parties came together to plan the first Yukon Storytelling Festival in 1988.

title: Yukon International Storytelling Festival
text: It later grew beyond the scope of Yukon and Canada to attract storytellers from all over the world with an emphasis on native peoples storytelling and circumpolar countries.

title: Yukon Energy
text: Yukon Energy Corporation (YEC) (French: "Société d’énergie du Yukon" ) is a Canadian Crown corporation in Yukon that provides electrical power to Yukon.

title: Yukon Energy
text: YEC is a subsidiary of Yukon Development Corporation that was established in 1987 to take over the Yukon assets of the Northern Canada Power Commission.

title: Yukon Energy
text: The company's headquarters is in Whitehorse, Yukon.

title: White Horse Rapids
text: The Whitehorse rapids were rapids on the Yukon River in Canada's Yukon Territory, named for their supposed resemblance to the mane of a charging white horse.

title: White Horse Rapids
text: The rapids formed where the Yukon River flows across and cuts down through lava flows of the Miles Canyon basalt.

title: White Horse Rapids
text: These rapids presented a major navigational obstacle on the Yukon River during the Klondike Gold Rush, and lent their name to the nearby town of Whitehorse.

title: Air North
text: Air North Charter and Training Ltd., operating as Air North, Yukon's Airline is a Canadian airline based in Whitehorse, Yukon.

title: Air North
text: It operates scheduled passenger and cargo flights, charter flights, and ground handling services throughout the Yukon, with regular flights to the Northwest Territories, Alaska, British Columbia, Alberta, and Ontario.

title: Air North
text: Its main base is Erik Nielsen Whitehorse International Airport.

title: 2014 Yukon/NWT Men's Curling Championship
text: The 2014 Yukon/NWT Men's Curling Championship, the men's curling championship for Yukon and the Northwest Territories, will be held from February 6 to 9 at the Whitehorse Curling Club in Whitehorse, Yukon.

title: 2014 Yukon/NWT Men's Curling Championship
text: The winning Jamie Koe rink from Yellowknife, Northwest Territories represented Yukon and the Northwest Territories at the 2014 Tim Hortons Brier in Kamloops.

title: Erik Nielsen Whitehorse International Airport
text: Erik Nielsen Whitehorse International Airport (IATA: YXY, ICAO: CYXY) is located in Whitehorse, Yukon, Canada.

title: Erik Nielsen Whitehorse International Airport
text: It is part of the National Airports System, and is owned and operated by the Government of Yukon.

title: Erik Nielsen Whitehorse International Airport
text: The airport was renamed in honour of longtime Yukon Member of Parliament Erik Nielsen on December 15, 2008.

title: Erik Nielsen Whitehorse International Airport
text: The terminal handled 294,000 passengers in 2012, representing a 94% increase in passenger traffic since 2002.

title: Erik Nielsen Whitehorse International Airport
text: Air North is based in Whitehorse.

title: 2012 Yukon/NWT Men's Curling Championship
text: The 2012 Yukon/NWT Men's Curling Championship was held February 9–12 at the Whitehorse Curling Club in Whitehorse, Yukon.

title: 2012 Yukon/NWT Men's Curling Championship
text: The winning team of Jamie Koe, will represent Yukon/Northwest Territories at the 2012 Tim Hortons Brier in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

title: Whitehorse Centre
text: Whitehorse Centre is an electoral district which returns a member (known as an MLA) to the Legislative Assembly of the Yukon Territory in Canada.

title: Whitehorse Centre
text: It was created in 1992 from an amalgamation of the ridings of Whitehorse North Centre and Whitehorse South Centre and readjusted in 2002 following the dissolution of the neighbouring riding of Riverside.

title: Whitehorse Centre
text: The riding encompasses the downtown core of the City of Whitehorse (including Marwell) between the escarpment and the Yukon River.

title: Whitehorse Centre
text: Whitehorse Centre is home to most of Whitehorse's businesses and government offices.

title: 2015 Yukon Men's Curling Championship
text: The 2015 Yukon Men's Curling Championship was held January 9 to 15 at the Whitehorse Curling Club in Whitehorse, Yukon.

title: 2015 Yukon Men's Curling Championship
text: It was the first territorial men's championship to be held since the Yukon gained a direct entry to the Brier, Canada's national men's curling championship.

title: 2015 Yukon Men's Curling Championship
text: Prior to 2015, the top two teams in the territory played in the Yukon/NWT Men's Curling Championship, with the winner going to the Brier.

title: 2015 Yukon Men's Curling Championship
text: The winning team represented the Yukon at the 2015 Tim Hortons Brier.

title: Rail transport in Walt Disney Parks and Resorts
text: Rail transport can be found in every theme park resort property owned or licensed by Walt Disney Parks and Resorts, the theme park and vacation resort segment of the larger Walt Disney Company.

title: Rail transport in Walt Disney Parks and Resorts
text: The origins of Disney theme park rail transport can be traced back to Walt Disney himself and his personal fondness for railroads, who insisted that they be included in the first Disney park, the original Disneyland (a key component of the Disneyland Resort) in California in the United States, which opened on July 17, 1955.

title: Rail transport in Walt Disney Parks and Resorts
text: The Disney tradition of including transport by rail in its parks has since been extended to other Disney properties with the opening of Walt Disney World in Florida in the United States, Tokyo Disney Resort in Japan, Disneyland Paris in France, Hong Kong Disneyland Resort in China, and Shanghai Disney Resort in China.

title: Djuan Rivers
text: Djuan Rivers is the Vice President of Disney's Animal Kingdom at Walt Disney World.

title: Djuan Rivers
text: He previously served as Vice President for Hotels and Business Solutions at Disneyland Paris after having been General Manager of the Disney Aulani Resort & Spa in Hawaii.

title: Brown's Hotel (Catskills)
text: Brown’s Hotel was a nationally known resort complex located in the Borscht Belt area of upstate New York, in the Catskill Mountains.

title: Brown's Hotel (Catskills)
text: It was one of the largest and most elaborate establishments of its kind during an era when the entire region prospered as a tourist destination.

title: Brown's Hotel (Catskills)
text: From the 1940s to the 1980s, the hotel was a popular vacation destination for many upper-middle-class families living in the New York City metropolitan area.

title: Brown's Hotel (Catskills)
text: Jewish-American families were welcomed and even catered to specifically by the hotels in the Borscht Belt during a time period when anti-semitism was prevalent in the hospitality industry.

title: Brown's Hotel (Catskills)
text: Filling a niche, the area quickly became a mecca for Jewish-American families.

title: Brown's Hotel (Catskills)
text: Brown's Hotel was located in the hamlet of Loch Sheldrake in the Town of Fallsburg, Sullivan County, New York.

title: Walt Disney World Swan
text: The Walt Disney World Swan is a resort hotel designed by architect Michael Graves located between Epcot and Disney's Hollywood Studios behind Disney's BoardWalk Resort and across from its sister resort, the Walt Disney World Dolphin.

title: Walt Disney World Swan
text: The Swan, which opened January 13, 1990 on Disney property, is a joint venture between the Walt Disney Company, Tishman Hotel Corporation, MetLife and Starwood Hotels and Resorts.

title: Walt Disney World Swan
text: The land the resort occupies is owned by the Walt Disney Company, while the buildings themselves are leased by Disney to the Tishman Hotel Corporation and MetLife and operated by Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide under the Westin brand.

title: Walt Disney World Swan
text: The Walt Disney World Swan and Dolphin are a part of the Walt Disney Collection of resorts, because of this they are Disney branded and guests of the resort have access to special Disney benefits available to Disney Resort Hotel guests only.

title: Disneytown
text: Disneytown is a shopping, dining, and entertainment complex at the Shanghai Disney Resort in Pudong, Shanghai, China.

title: Disneytown
text: It is the Shanghai Disney Resort equivalent of the Downtown Disney complex at Disneyland Resort in Anaheim, California; Disney Springs at the Walt Disney World Resort near Orlando, Florida; Ikspiari at Tokyo Disney Resort, and Disney Village at Disneyland Paris, France.

title: Ko Olina Resort
text: Ko Olina Resort is a 642 acre master-planned vacation and residential community on the leeward coast of Oahu, 17 mi northwest of Honolulu.

title: Ko Olina Resort
text: Ko Olina has 2 mi of coastal frontage and includes three natural and four man-made lagoons with white-sand beaches.

title: Ko Olina Resort
text: It is home to four hotel and vacation-club resorts: Aulani, a Disney Resort & Spa; the Ihilani Resort & Spa, Marriott's Ko Olina Beach Club, and The Four Seasons at Ko Olina, as well as several resort condominiums and villa homes.

title: Ko Olina Resort
text: Previously, the JW Marriott at Ko Olina occupied The Four Seasons property.

title: Ko Olina Resort
text: An Atlantis Resort, similar to Atlantis Dubai, is currently being designed as an international destination for millennial travelers.

title: Ko Olina Resort
text: The property will be adjacent to the condominiums located on lagoon three.

title: Disney's Saratoga Springs Resort & Spa
text: Disney's Saratoga Springs Resort & Spa is a Disney Vacation Club resort at the Walt Disney World Resort.

title: Disney's Saratoga Springs Resort & Spa
text: The resort is the seventh Disney Vacation Club resort and is situated on the former site of the Disney Institute.

title: Disney's Saratoga Springs Resort & Spa
text: It first opened May 17, 2004 and was built in three phases.

title: Disney's Saratoga Springs Resort & Spa
text: It is now the largest Disney Vacation Club resort.

title: Disney's Saratoga Springs Resort & Spa
text: The resort was inspired by the city of Saratoga Springs, New York.

title: Aulani
text: Aulani, a Disney Resort & Spa is a beachside hotel, resort and vacation destination offering complimentary children's activities and programs at the Ko Olina Resort & Marina in Kapolei on the Hawaiian island of Oahu.

title: Aulani
text: Part of the Disney Vacation Club, it is the third Disney Vacation Club Resort located outside of a Disney theme park property.

title: Aulani
text: The resort opened on August 29, 2011.

title: Walt Disney World Dolphin
text: The Walt Disney World Dolphin is a resort hotel designed by architect Michael Graves located between Epcot and Disney's Hollywood Studios in the Walt Disney World Resort in Bay Lake, Florida, next to Disney's BoardWalk Resort area.

title: Walt Disney World Dolphin
text: It opened on June 1, 1990 and is joined to its sister hotel, the Walt Disney World Swan (also designed by Graves) by a palm-tree lined covered walkway crossing a lagoon.

title: Walt Disney World Dolphin
text: The Walt Disney World Swan and Dolphin is a joint venture between the Walt Disney Company, Tishman Hotel Corporation, MetLife and Starwood Hotels and Resorts.

title: Walt Disney World Dolphin
text: The land the resort occupies is owned by the Walt Disney Company, while the buildings themselves are leased by Disney to the Tishman Hotel Corporation and MetLife but operated by Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide under the Sheraton Hotels brand.

title: Walt Disney World Dolphin
text: The Walt Disney World Swan and Dolphin are a part of the Walt Disney Collection of resorts; because of this they are Disney branded and guests of the resort have access to special Disney benefits available to Disney Resort Hotel guests only.

title: Horseshoe Resort
text: Horseshoe Resort, formerly Horseshoe Valley Ski Club, is a southern Ontario ski resort and four season vacation destination.

title: Horseshoe Resort
text: Located north of Barrie, the resort is about 1 hour 15 minutes driving time from Toronto.

title: Horseshoe Resort
text: The resort enjoys a long ski season due to snow making abilities.

title: Horseshoe Resort
text: Acquired by Skyline International Development Inc. in July 2007, Horseshoe Resort is spread out over 680 acres of land.

title: Horseshoe Resort
text: The resort offers two award-winning golf courses, a full-service Shizen Spa, 101 rooms at the on-site Inn and 40 condo-style suites, two year-round restaurants, 11,400 square feet of meeting and banquet facilities, indoor and outdoor swimming pools, a full gym and over 40 km of trails connected to the Copeland Forest suitable for hiking, biking and snowshoeing.

title: Jiangxia Tidal Power Station
text: The Jiangxia Tidal Power Station (江厦潮汐电站) is the fourth largest tidal power station in the world, located in Wuyantou, Wenling City, Zhejiang Province, China.

title: Jiangxia Tidal Power Station
text: Although the proposed design for the facility was 3,000 kW, the current installed capacity is 3,200 kW, generated from one unit of 500 kW, one unit of 600 kW, and three units of 700 kW, totalling the installed capacity to 3,200 kW.

title: Jiangxia Tidal Power Station
text: Proposals were made to install a sixth 700 kW unit, but this has not yet been installed.

title: Jiangxia Tidal Power Station
text: The facility generates up to 6.5 GWh of power annually.

title: Wenling Railway Station
text: Wenling Railway Station is a railway station of Yongtaiwen Railway located in Zhejiang, People's Republic of China.

title: Wenling
text: Wenling (Wenling dialect: Uen-lin Zy ] ; ) is a coastal county-level city in the municipal region of Taizhou, in southeastern Zhejiang province, China.

title: Wenling
text: It borders Luqiao and Huangyan to the north, Yuhuan to the south, Yueqing to the west, looks out to the East China Sea to the east.

title: Wenling
text: Wenling locates on 28°22'N, 121°21'E, approximately 300 km south of Shanghai.

title: Ke Zhao
text: Ke Zhao or Chao Ko (, April 12, 1910 – November 8, 2002) was a Chinese mathematician born in Wenling, Taizhou, Zhejiang, People's Republic of China.

title: Zhengzhou Xinzheng International Airport
text: Zhengzhou Xinzheng International Airport (IATA: CGO, ICAO: ZHCC) is the principal airport serving Zhengzhou, the capital of Henan Province, China.

title: Yandang Mountains
text: Yandang Mountains or Yandangshan (Chinese: 雁蕩山 , 雁荡山 , "Yàndàng Shān", "Wild Goose Pond Mountain(s)") refers, in the broad sense, to a coastal mountain range in southeastern Zhejiang province in eastern China, covering much of the prefecture-level city of Wenzhou (from Pingyang County in the south to Yueqing County in the northeast) and extending to the county-level city of Wenling in Taizhou prefecture.

title: Yandang Mountains
text: The mountain range is divided in two by the Oujiang River, the two parts being the North Yandang and South Yandang.

title: Yandang Mountains
text: More narrowly, Yandangshan is also used more narrowly to refer to Mount Yandang , a specific part of the North Yandang around an ancient caldera near a small town of the same name (雁荡镇 , "Yàndàng Zhèn").

title: Yandang Mountains
text: The highest peaks of North Yandang are located here, and this is also the main tourist spot.

title: Yandang Mountains
text: In this article, name "Yandang Mountains" is used to refer the mountain range and "Mt. Yandang" to refer to the caldera.

title: Zhongyuan Airlines
text: Zhongyuan Airlines (中原航空 "Zhōngyuán Hángkōng") was an airline based in Zhengzhou, Henan Province, People's Republic of China.

title: Zhongyuan Airlines
text: Its main base was Zhengzhou Xinzheng International Airport.

title: SIAS International University
text: Sias International University (Sias, Chinese: 郑州大学西亚斯国际学院 zhèng-zhōu dà-xué xī-yà-sī guó-jì xué-yuàn), transliterated Zhengzhou University Sias International College, is the first solely American-owned post-secondary school in Central China.
keywords_text: 郑州大学西亚斯国际学院_zhèng-zhōu

title: SIAS International University
text: Officially a campus of, and affiliated with Zhengzhou University, the leading university in Henan Province, it was developed and designed to meet the most current educational needs of students in China.

title: SIAS International University
text: It is the first full-time undergraduate institution approved by the Degree Committee of the State Council in China to grant both Chinese and American bachelor's degrees, whose diplomas are those of Zhengzhou University and Fort Hays State University.

title: SIAS International University
text: It is fully accredited by the Chinese Ministry of Education.

title: SIAS International University
text: Sias is located in the ancient city of Xinzheng, near Henan's capital, Zhengzhou.

title: Xinzheng
text: Xinzheng () is a small county-level city of Zhengzhou in the south of Henan province of Central China.

title: Xinzheng
text: The city has a population of 600,000 people and covers an area of 15 km2 .

title: Peiligang culture
text: The Peiligang culture is the name given by archaeologists to a group of Neolithic communities in the Yi-Luo river basin in Henan Province, China.

title: Peiligang culture
text: The culture existed from 7000 to 5000 BC.

title: Peiligang culture
text: Over 100 sites have been identified with the Peiligang culture, nearly all of them in a fairly compact area of about 100 square kilometers in the area just south of the river and along its banks.

title: Peiligang culture
text: The culture is named after the site discovered in 1977 at Peiligang, a village in Xinzheng County.

title: Peiligang culture
text: Archaeologists think that the Peiligang culture was egalitarian, with little political organization.

title: Pete Tillotson
text: Peter S. Tillotson (born March 23, 1936) is an American former basketball player.

title: Pete Tillotson
text: He grew up in Ludington, Michigan, and played basketball for Ludington High School from 1951 to 1954.

title: Pete Tillotson
text: In three years at Ludington High, he scored 1,176 points -- 179 points as a sophomore, 433 points as a junior and 564 points as a senior.

title: Pete Tillotson
text: During the 1953–54 season, he averaged 25.6 points per game.

title: Pete Tillotson
text: He led Ludington to a 21–2 record and the state finals in 1952 and an 18–4 record in 1953.

title: Pete Tillotson
text: As a student at the University of Michigan, he played center for the Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team from 1955 to 1958.

title: Pete Tillotson
text: He was the captain, most valuable player, and leading scorer on the 1957–58 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team.

title: Pete Tillotson
text: He scored 415 points during the 1957–58 season (an average of 18.8 points per game), the second highest point total in Michigan's history to that point.

title: Pete Tillotson
text: Tillotson was drafted by the Syracuse Nationals in the fifth round (53rd overall pick) of the 1958 NBA draft.

title: Pete Tillotson
text: He was injured during the pre-season training camp for Syracuse and spent the 1958–59 season playing for the Milan Simmenthal in the Italian Amateur League.

title: Pete Tillotson
text: He led Milan to a second-place finish for the European championship while averaging 18 points and 11 rebounds.

title: Pete Tillotson
text: He played for Syracuse in 1960, but his playing career ended after he sustained a knee injury.

title: Pete Tillotson
text: After retiring from basketball, Tillotson worked for nearly 40 years for Ford Motor Company, Paine Webber, Goldman Sachs and General Electric.

title: Pete Tillotson
text: He retired in 2001.

title: Pete Tillotson
text: He was included in the inaugural class of seven athletes inducted into the Mason County Sports Hall of Fame in 2005.

title: Michigan–Michigan State men's basketball rivalry
text: The Michigan–Michigan State basketball rivalry is a college basketball rivalry between Michigan Wolverines men's basketball and Michigan State Spartans men's basketball that is part of the larger intrastate rivalry between the University of Michigan and Michigan State University that exists across a broad spectrum of endeavors including their general athletic programs: Michigan Wolverines and Michigan State Spartans.

title: Michigan–Michigan State men's basketball rivalry
text: On the field, the athletic rivalry includes the Paul Bunyan Trophy and the Michigan–Michigan State ice hockey rivalry, but extends to almost all sports and many other forms of achievement.

title: Michigan–Michigan State men's basketball rivalry
text: Both teams are members of the Big Ten Conference.

title: Michigan–Michigan State men's basketball rivalry
text: The rivalry has been evidenced both on the court and off the court.

title: Michigan–Michigan State men's basketball rivalry
text: Among the off the court elements of the rivalry, recruiting of basketball talent has resulted in battles, the most notable of which turned into the University of Michigan basketball scandal when both schools sought the services of Mateen Cleaves.

title: 2014–15 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The 2014–15 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team represented the University of Michigan during the 2014–15 NCAA Division I men's basketball season.

title: 2014–15 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The team played its home games in Ann Arbor, Michigan for the 48th consecutive year at the Crisler Center, which has a capacity of 12,707.

title: 2014–15 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: This season marked the program's 99th season and its 98th consecutive year as a member of the Big Ten Conference.

title: 2014–15 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The team was led by 8th year head coach John Beilein, who was voted 2014 Big Ten Coach of the Year by the Big Ten media.

title: 2014–15 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The 2013–14 team was Big Ten champion, earning the school's first outright title since 1986.

title: 2014–15 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The program entered the season coming off its winningest two-year stretch, having won 59 games in the two previous seasons.

title: 2014–15 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The team was also coming off four consecutive NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament appearances.

title: 2012–13 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The 2012–13 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team represented the University of Michigan during the 2012–13 NCAA Division I men's basketball season.

title: 2012–13 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: For the 46th consecutive year, the Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team played its home games in Ann Arbor, Michigan, at the Crisler Center.

title: 2012–13 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: This season marked the team's 96th consecutive year as a member of the Big Ten Conference, and it is occasionally referred to as "Team 96".

title: 2012–13 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The team was led by sixth-year head coach John Beilein.

title: 2012–13 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: As the defending 2011–12 Big Ten Conference men's basketball season regular season co-champions, the Wolverines finished fourth in the conference in 2012–13 and as National Runner-up in the 2013 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament after losing in the championship game to Louisville.

title: 2012–13 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The team achieved a 31–8 record, the most wins by the program in 20 seasons.

title: Estel Tessmer
text: Estel S. "Zit" Tessmer (February 25, 1910 – June 1972) was an American football and basketball player.

title: Estel Tessmer
text: A native of Ann Arbor, Michigan, Tessmer attended the University of Michigan where he played for the football and basketball teams.

title: Estel Tessmer
text: He played as a quarterback for the Michigan Wolverines football teams from 1929 to 1931 and 1933.

title: Estel Tessmer
text: He won the Chicago Alumni Trophy as a freshman in football.

title: Estel Tessmer
text: He started three games at the quarterback position in 1930 and three more in 1931, but his playing time at quarterback was limited because the 1930 and 1931 Wolverines included College Football Hall of Fame quarterback Harry Newman.

title: Estel Tessmer
text: After losing the starting quarterback job to Newman, Tessmer also played some games at the right halfback position.

title: Estel Tessmer
text: Tessmer also played three years as a guard for the Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team from 1931 to 1934.

title: Estel Tessmer
text: He later became a teacher and basketball coach at Bay City Central High School.

title: Estel Tessmer
text: He also threw two no-hit games as a baseball pitcher in intramural sports while attending Michigan.

title: Estel Tessmer
text: He was basketball coach at Bay City through 1953 and remained athletic director at the school thereafter.

title: Estel Tessmer
text: Tessmer died in 1972 at age 61.

title: Estel Tessmer
text: He was a resident of Bay City, Michigan at the time of his death.

title: 1951–52 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The 1951–52 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team represented the University of Michigan in intercollegiate basketball during the 1951–52 season.

title: 1951–52 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: In their fourth season under head coach Ernie McCoy, the Wolverines team compiled a 7–15 record and finished in a tie for eighth place in the Big Ten Conference.

title: 1951–52 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: Senior Jim Skala was the team captain, leading scorer and Most Valuable Player.

title: 1951–52 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The team was notable as the first racially integrated Michigan basketball team with Don Eaddy and John Codwell becoming the first two African-American players.

title: Charles Matthews (basketball)
text: Charles I. Matthews (born November 15, 1996) is an American basketball player for the Michigan Wolverines who sat out the season for the 2016-17 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team.

title: Charles Matthews (basketball)
text: He played his freshman season for the 2015–16 Kentucky Wildcats men's basketball team after attending St. Rita of Cascia High School.

title: Charles Matthews (basketball)
text: As a high school senior he was a 2015 Jordan Brand Classic All-American selection.

title: Ferris Jennings
text: Ferris Gordon Jennings (November 10, 1913 – December 22, 1995) was an American football, baseball and basketball player.

title: Ferris Jennings
text: He played college football at the quarterback and safety positions for the University of Michigan in 1934 and 1936.

title: Ferris Jennings
text: He was the starting quarterback for the 1934 Michigan Wolverines football team.

title: Ferris Jennings
text: Jennings also played for the Michigan Wolverines men's basketball and Michigan Wolverines baseball teams between 1935 and 1937.

title: 1980–81 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The 1980–81 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team represented the University of Michigan in intercollegiate college basketball during the 1980–81 NCAA Division I men's basketball season.

title: 1980–81 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The team played its home games in the Crisler Arena in Ann Arbor, Michigan, and was a member of the Big Ten Conference.

title: 1980–81 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: Under the direction of first-year head coach Bill Frieder, the team finished tied for sixth in the Big Ten Conference.

title: 1980–81 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The team earned an invitation to the 1981 National Invitation Tournament.

title: 1980–81 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: Although the team was ranked in the Associated Press Top Twenty Poll for eleven of the sixteen weeks reaching a peak at number nine, it began and finished the season unranked and it also ended the season unranked in the final UPI Coaches' Poll.

title: 1980–81 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The team was led by All-American Mike McGee.

title: 1980–81 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: The team set the current Big Ten conference record by playing in six overtime games.

title: 1980–81 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: That season McGee also set the current conference record for career field goals attempted (2077).

title: 1980–81 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: McGee set several other records, which have since been broken: career points (2439, broken in 1989 by Glen Rice), career points (conference games only) (1503, broken in 1995), single-season field goals made (309, broken in 1986) and career field goals made (1010, broken in 1993).

title: 1980–81 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team
text: Mark Bodnar became the first Michigan Wolverines player on record to total 13 assists in a game on December 13, 1980, against the Dayton Flyers

title: John Beilein
text: John Patrick Beilein (pronounced "bee-line"; born February 5, 1953) is an American college basketball coach and current men's basketball head coach at the University of Michigan.

title: John Beilein
text: He is the 16th head coach of the Michigan Wolverines.

title: John Beilein
text: The 2016–17 season is his tenth at Michigan.

title: John Beilein
text: Beilein has won 691 career games at four-year universities and 766 games altogether, including those at the junior college level.

title: John Beilein
text: He has previously coached the West Virginia Mountaineers (2002–2007), Richmond Spiders (1997–2002), Canisius Golden Griffins (1992–1997) in NCAA Division I as well as Le Moyne College (1983–1992), Nazareth College (1982–1983) and Erie Community College (1978–1982).

title: New Orleans Film Society
text: The New Orleans Film Society (NOFS) is a nonprofit arts organization located in New Orleans, Louisiana.

title: New Orleans Film Society
text: The organization presents and exhibits year-round film programming and events in addition to the annual New Orleans Film Festival.

title: Newswomen's Club of New York
text: The Newswomen's Club of New York is a nonprofit organization that focuses on women working in the media in the New York City metropolitan area.

title: Newswomen's Club of New York
text: It was founded in 1922 as the New York Newspaper Woman’s Club and included such well-known individuals as Eleanor Roosevelt, Helen Rogers Reid and Anne O'Hare McCormick among its membership; it changed its name in 1971 to include members working in magazines and broadcast media.

title: Newswomen's Club of New York
text: The organization presents its Front Page Award annually to honor the most prominent achievements by women in journalism.

title: Chris Noonan
text: Chris Noonan (born 14 November 1952) is a Sydney-based Australian filmmaker and actor best known for the family film "Babe" (1995), for which he was nominated for both the Academy Award for Best Director and Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay.

title: Alabama Broadcasters Association
text: The Alabama Broadcasters Association (ABA) represents radio and television broadcasters across the U.S. state of Alabama.

title: Alabama Broadcasters Association
text: It is affiliated with the National Association of Broadcasters.

title: Alabama Broadcasters Association
text: Every year the organization presents the ABBY (Alabama's Best in Broadcasting Yearly) Awards.

title: Alabama Broadcasters Association
text: The organization also has a Hall of Fame .

title: Public Art Fund
text: Public Art Fund is an independent, non-profit arts organization founded in 1977 by Doris C. Freedman.

title: Public Art Fund
text: The organization presents contemporary art in New York City's public spaces through a series of highly visible artists' projects, new commissions, installations, and exhibitions that are emblematic of the organization's mission and innovative history.

title: Public Art Fund
text: Nicholas Baume joined PAF as Director & Chief Curator in 2009, and Susan K. Freedman has served as the President since 1986.

title: Academy Award for Best Director
text: The Academy Award for Best Director (officially known as the Academy Award for Best Directing) is an award presented annually by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS).

title: Academy Award for Best Director
text: It is given in honor of a film director who has exhibited outstanding directing while working in the film industry.

title: Babe (film)
text: Babe is a 1995 Australian-American comedy-drama film directed by Chris Noonan, produced by George Miller, and written by both.

title: Babe (film)
text: It is an adaptation of Dick King-Smith's 1983 novel "The Sheep-Pig", also known as "Babe: The Gallant Pig" in the US, which tells the story of a pig who wants to be a sheepdog.

title: Babe (film)
text: The main animal characters are played by a combination of real and animatronic pigs and Border Collies.

title: The Center for Arts in Natick
text: The Center for Arts in Natick, also known as TCAN (pronounced tee-can) in Natick, Massachusetts, is a regional community arts organization serving the cities and towns of MetroWest Boston.

title: The Center for Arts in Natick
text: It has been in existence in various locations since 1997.

title: The Center for Arts in Natick
text: The organization presents more than 300 events, classes and performances each year attended by over 24,000 patrons annually.

title: The Center for Arts in Natick
text: TCAN was established as a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization in 1997.

title: Office of the Chief Trade Adviser
text: The Office of the Chief Trade Adviser (OCTA) is an independent trade advisory body of the Forum Island Countries.

title: Office of the Chief Trade Adviser
text: OCTA provides policy advice and capacity building support to the Forum Island Countries, particularly in the Pacific Agreement on Closer Economic Relations (PACER) Plus trade negotiations with Australia and New Zealand.

title: Office of the Chief Trade Adviser
text: OCTA was established on 29 March 2010 and is based in Port Vila, Vanuatu.

title: Office of the Chief Trade Adviser
text: The first to be appointed to the Chief Trade Adviser position was Chris Noonan, an academic from New Zealand.

title: Office of the Chief Trade Adviser
text: Noonan resigned in September 2011.

title: Office of the Chief Trade Adviser
text: The OCTA Governing Board then appointed Julia Tijaja, the Trade Policy Adviser, as Caretaker Chief Trade Adviser in the interim until the new Chief Trade Adviser came on board.

title: Office of the Chief Trade Adviser
text: In February 2012, Edwini Kessie, an international trade law expert, was appointed the new Chief Trade Adviser.

title: Office of the Chief Trade Adviser
text: Kessie took up his post in June 2012.

title: Office of the Chief Trade Adviser
text: Thirteen Forum Island Countries are currently members of the OCTA; Cook Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, Kiribati, Nauru, Niue, Palau, Papua New Guinea, Marshal Islands, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Tuvalu and Vanuatu.

title: Office of the Chief Trade Adviser
text: OCTA is fully owned and is under the exclusive control of its members.

title: League of American Orchestras
text: The League of American Orchestras, formerly the American Symphony Orchestra League, is a North American Musical Organization consisting of a network of approximately 800 orchestras.

title: League of American Orchestras
text: “Dedicated to helping orchestras meet the challenges of the twenty-first century,” the League consists of leading symphony and philharmonic orchestras, collegiate orchestras, community ensembles, and youth and student ensembles.

title: League of American Orchestras
text: The only national organization devoted and focused on elevating the orchestra industry, the League was founded in 1942 and later chartered by Congress in 1962.

title: League of American Orchestras
text: The League creates a network of all facets of the industry, including administrators, managers, board members, business partners, volunteers, and musicians.

title: League of American Orchestras
text: Each year this organization presents two awards: the Gold Baton Award and the Helen M. Thompson Award.

title: League of American Orchestras
text: The League affects the orchestral world through several outreach experiences, dedicated advocacy to music education and especially orchestral education, and maintaining and communicating a breadth of information and pertinent topics in publications.

title: League of American Orchestras
text: It has also developed detailed antitrust policy and guidelines in order to comply with the landscape of the industry.

title: League of American Orchestras
text: The League is a leading force in work on legislation regarding orchestras and support for the arts.

title: Defence Strategic Policy and Intelligence Group
text: The Defence Strategic Policy and Intelligence Group (SP&I) of the Australian Government Department of Defence is responsible for defence diplomacy, strategic policy, international security, and military intelligence coordination and advice to the Prime Minister of Australia, Minister for Defence, Secretary of the Department of Defence, and Chief of the Defence Force.

title: Defence Strategic Policy and Intelligence Group
text: The Defence Strategic Policy and Intelligence Group is led by the Deputy Secretary for Strategic Policy and Intelligence and comprises four policy divisions and three intelligence agencies, which are the Australian Defence Organisation members of the Australian Intelligence Community.

title: British intelligence agencies
text: The Government of the United Kingdom maintains intelligence agencies within several different government departments.

title: British intelligence agencies
text: The agencies are responsible for collecting and producing foreign and domestic intelligence, providing military intelligence, performing espionage and counter-espionage.

title: British intelligence agencies
text: Their intelligence assessments contribute to the conduct of the foreign relations of the United Kingdom, maintaining the national security of the United Kingdom, military planning and law enforcement in the United Kingdom.

title: British intelligence agencies
text: The three main agencies are the Secret Intelligence Service (MI6), the Security Service (MI5), and the Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ).

title: Gustav Laabs
text: Gustav Laabs (born 20 December 1902-died 12 March 1980) was a German SS commander during the Nazi era.

title: Gustav Laabs
text: During the Second World War, he worked as a gas van operator at the Chełmno extermination camp in Wartheland.

title: Gustav Laabs
text: As an operator of a gas van, Laabs was directly involved in and responsible for the genocidal extermination of over 100,000 men, women and children, most of whom were killed on account of being Jewish.

title: Gustav Laabs
text: After the war, he was tried and convicted for his crimes against humanity.

title: Gustav Laabs
text: Despite being convicted, Laabs was given the lenient sentence of 15 years (subsequently reduced to 13 years) by a regional court in Landgericht Bonn, Germany.

title: Gustav Laabs
text: Far from being outliers, such instances of leniency, extended to perpetrators of genocide and crimes against humanity during trials in post-Nazi Germany, constituted the norm, as evidenced by the fact that most of the perpetrators of Nazi war crimes and the Final Solution were not brought to justice.

title: Gustav Laabs
text: Many former SS officers and Nazis, who were directly responsible for perpetrating genocide and murdering countless innocent people, were contracted to work for US and British intelligence agencies as part of the war against the USSR and Communism (also see Operation Paperclip for more on post-WWII Allied collaboration with Nazis).

title: Alliance Base
text: Alliance Base was the cover name for a secret Western Counterterrorist Intelligence Center (CTIC) that existed between 2002 and 2009 in Paris.

title: Alliance Base
text: The existence of CTICs were first revealed by Dana Priest in a November 17, 2005 "Washington Post" article, while she referred to the Alliance Base in a July 2, 2005, article.

title: Alliance Base
text: The name was chosen in reference of Al Qaeda, which means "The Base" in Arabic.

title: Alliance Base
text: It was headed by a French General assigned to the Directorate-General for External Security (DGSE), and largely funded by the CIA's Counterterrorist Center.

title: Alliance Base
text: It hosted officers from Great Britain, France, Germany, Canada, Australia and the United States and was used for intelligence exchange and operational planning.

title: Alliance Base
text: Its existence was confirmed on 8 September 2006 by Christophe Chaboud, chief of the UCLAT (""Unité de Coordination de la Lutte contre le Terrorisme"", "Fight against Terrorism Coordination Unit"), in an interview to RFI.

title: Alliance Base
text: Although intelligence exchange between intelligence agencies has become more and more widespread in the last decade, in particular following the September 11, 2001 attacks, this organisation also engaged in operations.

title: Yulin Naval Base
text: Yulin Naval Base () is a naval base for nuclear submarines along the southern coast of Hainan Island, People's Republic of China.

title: Yulin Naval Base
text: This underground base has been reported by several intelligence agencies, especially Indian agencies.

title: Yulin Naval Base
text: The images collected by the Federation of American Scientists (FAS) in February 2008 shows that China constructed a large scale underground base for its naval forces.

title: Ardeshir Reporter
text: Sir Ardeshir Reporter was born in a Zoroastrian Parsee family in Bombay on August 22, 1865.

title: Ardeshir Reporter
text: He was a secret British Intelligence agent in Iran for many years.

title: Ardeshir Reporter
text: In fact, he lived and worked in Iran as a secret British Intelligence agent since 1893.

title: Ardeshir Reporter
text: He came to Iran under the cover of Times' reporter.

title: Ardeshir Reporter
text: It was he who introduced General Ironside to Reza Khan, and it was Ironside who encouraged Reza Khan to seize power.

title: Ardeshir Reporter
text: According to his own will, he was the one, who discovered Reza Khan and guided him in the coup on February 22, 1921.

title: Ardeshir Reporter
text: Therefore he was instrumental in Reza Khan’s 1921 military coup and the consequent establishment of the Pahlavi dynasty and enthronement of Reza Shah in Iran in 1925.

title: Ardeshir Reporter
text: Ardeshir Reporter died in Tehran in 1933.

title: Ardeshir Reporter
text: His son, Shapoor Reporter, was also a secret agent of the British Intelligence Service in Iran who served the Pahlavi family after Reza Shah's death.

title: Australian Secret Intelligence Service
text: The Australian Secret Intelligence Service (ASIS; ) is Australia's foreign intelligence agency.

title: Australian Secret Intelligence Service
text: ASIS was formed in 1952, but its existence remained secret even within the Government until 1972.

title: Australian Secret Intelligence Service
text: ASIS is part of the Australian Intelligence Community responsible for the collection of foreign intelligence, including both counter-intelligence and liaising with the intelligence agencies of other countries.

title: Australian Secret Intelligence Service
text: In these roles, ASIS is comparable to the British Secret Intelligence Service (MI6) and the American Central Intelligence Agency (CIA).

title: Defense Intelligence Agency in popular culture
text: The Defense Intelligence Agency (DIA) is a military espionage organization of the United States and one of the country's national-level intelligence agencies under the jurisdiction of the U.S. Department of Defense (DoD).

title: Defense Intelligence Agency in popular culture
text: Less known than its non-DoD equivalent or its cryptologic counterpart, the DIA and its personnel have at times been portrayed in works of American popular culture.

title: Defense Intelligence Agency in popular culture
text: As with other U.S. foreign intelligence organizations, the agency's role has occasionally been confused with those of law enforcement agencies.

title: Government Communications Headquarters
text: The Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ) is an intelligence and security organisation responsible for providing signals intelligence (SIGINT) and information assurance to the government and armed forces of the United Kingdom.

title: Government Communications Headquarters
text: Based in "The Doughnut" in the suburbs of Cheltenham, GCHQ is the responsibility of the country's Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs, but it is not a part of the Foreign Office and its director ranks as a Permanent Secretary.

title: Israel's Secret Wars
text: It explores the role of secret intelligence and covert activities in the Zionist movement before independence and explore the operational and political histories all three major Israeli intelligence agencies Aman (military intelligence), Mossad (foreign intelligence and covert operations) and Shin Bet (internal security).

title: When a Man Falls in Love
text: When a Man Falls in Love () is a 2013 South Korean television series, starring Song Seung-heon, Shin Se-kyung, Chae Jung-an, and Yeon Woo-jin.

title: When a Man Falls in Love
text: The story revolves around a world-weary gangster as his love life intertwines with three others, and how the course of their lives changes entirely based on one moment of fevered passion.

title: When a Man Falls in Love
text: It aired on MBC from April 3 to June 6, 2013 on Wednesdays and Thursdays at 21:55 for 20 episodes.

title: The 1st Shop of Coffee Prince
text: The 1st Shop of Coffee Prince (; also known as Coffee Prince) is a 2007 South Korean television drama, starring Yoon Eun-hye, Gong Yoo, Lee Sun-kyun, and Chae Jung-an.

title: The 1st Shop of Coffee Prince
text: Based on the novel of the same name written by Lee Sun-mi, the hit series aired on MBC from July 2 to August 28, 2007 on Mondays and Tuesdays at 21:55 for 17 episodes.

title: A New Leaf (TV series)
text: A New Leaf () is a 2014 South Korean television series starring Kim Myung-min, Park Min-young, Kim Sang-joong and Chae Jung-an.

title: A New Leaf (TV series)
text: It aired on MBC from April 30 to June 26, 2014 on Wednesdays and Thursdays at 21:55 for 16 episodes.

title: Man to Man (TV series)
text: Man to Man () is a 2017 South Korean television series starring Park Hae-jin, Park Sung-woong, Kim Min-jung, Chae Jung-an and Yeon Jung-hoon.

title: Man to Man (TV series)
text: The show airs on JTBC every Friday and Saturday at 11:00pm KST.

title: Chae Jung-an
text: Chae Jung-An (born Jang Jung-An on September 9, 1977) is a South Korean actress and singer.

title: Cain and Abel (TV series)
text: Cain and Abel () is a 2009 South Korean television series starring So Ji-sub, Shin Hyun-joon, Han Ji-min, and Chae Jung-an.

title: Cain and Abel (TV series)
text: It aired on SBS from February 18 to April 23, 2009 on Wednesdays and Thursdays at 21:55 for 20 episodes.

title: Emperor of the Sea
text: Emperor of the Sea (; literally "Sea God") is a South Korean television drama series starring Choi Soo-jong, Chae Shi-ra, Song Il-gook، Soo Ae and Chae Jung-an It aired on KBS2 from November 24, 2004 to May 25, 2005 on Wednesdays and Thursdays at 21:55 for 51 episodes.

title: Emperor of the Sea
text: The period drama is based on Choi In-ho's 2003 novel "Hae-sin", which depicts the life of Jang Bogo, who rises from a lowly slave to a powerful maritime figure who dominated the East Asia seas and international trade during the Unified Silla Dynasty.

title: Prime Minister and I
text: Prime Minister and I () is a 2013 South Korean television drama starring Im Yoon-ah, Lee Beom-soo, Yoon Shi-yoon, Chae Jung-an and Ryu Jin.

title: Prime Minister and I
text: It aired on KBS2 from December 9, 2013 to February 4, 2014 on Mondays and Tuesdays at 22:00 for 17 episodes.

title: Queen of Reversals
