text: The development of a new golf course and an additional housing development have started a growth trend that may eventually double the size of the community.

title: Lynd, Minnesota
text: It is primarily a bedroom community for individuals who work in the nearby city of Marshall.

title: Lynd, Minnesota
text: Despite being much smaller in size, it historically played a more significant role in the area.

title: Lynd, Minnesota
text: The Kiel and Morgan Hotel in the town was the original Lyon County seat.

title: Carencro, Louisiana
text: Carencro ( ; historically French: "St.-Pierre" ) is a small city in Lafayette Parish, Louisiana.

title: Carencro, Louisiana
text: It is a suburb of the nearby city of Lafayette.

title: Carencro, Louisiana
text: The population was 7,526 at the 2010 census, up from 6,120 at the 2000 census.

title: Carencro, Louisiana
text: Its name comes from the Cajun French word for buzzard: the spot was one where large flocks of buzzards roosted in the bald cypress trees.

title: Carencro, Louisiana
text: The name means "carrion crow."

title: Burns, Oregon
text: Burns is a city in and the county seat of Harney County, in the U.S. state of Oregon.

title: Burns, Oregon
text: According to the 2010 census, the population was 2,806.

title: Burns, Oregon
text: Burns and the nearby city of Hines are home to about 60 percent of the people in the sparsely populated county, the largest in Oregon and the ninth largest in the United States.

title: Mount Vernon, Iowa
text: Mount Vernon is a city in Linn County, Iowa, United States, adjacent to the city of Lisbon.

title: Mount Vernon, Iowa
text: The city's population was 3,390 when the 2000 census figures were released, but that number was later revised to 3,808 because the Census Bureau had incorrectly reported that 418 residents of a Cornell College dormitory in Mount Vernon lived in the nearby city of Bertram.

title: Mount Vernon, Iowa
text: A special census taken by the city in 2004 counted 4,171 residents.

title: Mount Vernon, Iowa
text: The population was 4,506 at the 2010 census.

title: Mount Vernon, Iowa
text: Mount Vernon is part of the Cedar Rapids Metropolitan Statistical Area.

title: Collins, Mississippi
text: Collins is a city in Covington County, Mississippi, United States.

title: Collins, Mississippi
text: The population was 2,586 at the 2010 census.

title: Collins, Mississippi
text: It is the county seat of Covington County.

title: Spring Creek, Nevada
text: Spring Creek is a census-designated place (CDP) in central Elko County, in northeastern Nevada in the western United States.

title: Spring Creek, Nevada
text: It mainly serves as a bedroom community for the businesses and industries in and around the nearby city of Elko.

title: Spring Creek, Nevada
text: It is part of the Elko Micropolitan Statistical Area.

title: Spring Creek, Nevada
text: The population was 12,361 at the 2010 census.

title: Hot Coffee, Mississippi
text: Hot Coffee is a locale in Covington County, Mississippi, celebrated in local Mississippi lore.

title: Hot Coffee, Mississippi
text: It is sometimes assigned the same zipcode as nearby Collins.

title: Dibble, Oklahoma
text: Dibble is a town in McClain County, Oklahoma, United States.

title: Dibble, Oklahoma
text: The population within city limits was 878 at the 2010 census.

title: Dibble, Oklahoma
text: The town was named after two brothers, James and John Dibble.

title: Dibble, Oklahoma
text: The community has 8,868 residents in its 73031 zipcode, according to Sperling's Best Places.

title: Dibble, Oklahoma
text: Dibble is in the outer suburban area west of Purcell, OK, and southwest of Norman, OK, in the Oklahoma City Metropolitan Area, according to the U.S. Census Bureau.

title: Huaihua
text: Huaihua () is a prefecture-level city in the south western Hunan, China.

title: Huaihua
text: it covers 27,564 km2 and is bordered by Xiangxi to the northern west; Zhangjiajie, Changde to the north; Yiyang, Loudi and Shaoyang to the east; Guilin and Liuzhou of Guangxi to the south; Qiandongnan, Tongren of Guizhou to the southern west.

title: Huaihua
text: It has 4,741,948 of population (2010 census), shares 7.22% of the province.

title: Huaihua
text: According to 2010 Census, there are 2,909,574 Han Chinese, Han shares 61.4% of the population, 1,832,289 population of minorities, 38.6%; Dong, Miao, Tujia, Yao and Bai are major native minorities.

title: Huaihua
text: Huaihua is the central region of Dong ethnic population, there lives 816,481 Dong people (2010 census), it shares 28.35 per centage of Chinese Dong ethnic group.

title: David Oliver (hurdler)
text: David Oliver (born April 24, 1982), is an American hurdling athlete.

title: David Oliver (hurdler)
text: As a professional athlete, he competes in the 110 meter hurdles event outdoor and the 60 meter hurdles event indoor.

title: David Oliver (hurdler)
text: He is the former 110 meter hurdles champion winning the gold medal at the World Championships in Moscow with a time of 13 seconds.

title: David Oliver (hurdler)
text: He won the bronze medal in the 2008 Olympic Games and won another bronze at the 2010 IAAF World Indoor Championships.

title: Maj Jacobsson
text: Maj Jacobsson (25 November 1909 – 31 January 1996) was a Swedish athlete who won the 80 m hurdles event at the 1930 Women's World Games.

title: Maj Jacobsson
text: Domestically she won eight titles in 1929–1930, in the 80 m, 80 m hurdles, 200 m, long jump and standing long jump.

title: Ross Baillie
text: Ross Baillie (26 September 1977 – 18 June 1999) was a Scottish track and field athlete, older brother of Commonwealth Silver medal winner Chris Baillie.

title: Ross Baillie
text: Both his parents were also track and field athletes, father Hugh representing Great Britain at 400m, and mother Sheila being a former Scottish champion at 80m hurdles (superseded by the 100m hurdles since 1968).

title: Ross Baillie
text: Deemed by Colin Jackson to be his natural successor in the 110m hurdles event for Great Britain, he died at the age of 21.

title: Ross Baillie
text: Fittingly, since his death, the records set by Ross have been broken by his brother.

title: Oluwatobiloba Amusan
text: Oluwatobiloba Ayomide Amusan (born April 23, 1997) is a Nigerian sprinter.

title: Oluwatobiloba Amusan
text: She claimed gold in the 100 metres hurdles event at the 2015 African Junior Athletics Championships in Addis Ababa.

title: Oluwatobiloba Amusan
text: In 2015, while making her All-Africa Games debut, she won gold in the 100 metres hurdles event at the 2015 All-Africa Games.

title: Oluwatobiloba Amusan
text: Her team mate, Lindsay Lindley was third.

title: Oluwatobiloba Amusan
text: She was also a silver medallist at the 2013 African Youth Championships in Warri.

title: Aron Koech
text: Aron Kipchumba Koech (also known as Haron Koech; born 27 January 1990) is a Kenyan hurdler.

title: Aron Koech
text: At the 2015 Athletics Kenya World Championship Trials he finished third in the 400 metres hurdles event.

title: Aron Koech
text: Later that year he represented Kenya in the 400 metres hurdles event at the 2015 World Championships in Athletics in Beijing, China.

title: Aron Koech
text: With a personal best, in a time of 49.38, he finished 22nd in the heats.

title: Aron Koech
text: He was qualified for the semi finals where he finished 19th in a time of 49.54.

title: Aron Koech
text: Again in 2016 he finished third at the 2016 Athletics Kenya Olympic Trials behind his brother and Boniface Mucheru Tumuti.

title: Aron Koech
text: At the Olympics, Koech made the final while his brother was disqualified in the heats.

title: Aron Koech
text: Tumuti went on to capture the silver medal in National Record time, while Koech finished seventh.

title: Aron Koech
text: His 48.49 in the semi final round is her personal record.

title: Edith Noeding
text: Edith Noeding (born November 3, 1954 in Lobitos District) is a retired female track and field athlete from Peru, who competed in the hurdles event during her career.

title: Edith Noeding
text: She won the gold medal at the 1975 Pan American Games in the women's 100 metres hurdles event.

title: Edith Noeding
text: There Noeding set her personal best in the women's 100 metres hurdles event on October 19, 1975, clocking 13.56 in Mexico City.

title: Edith Noeding
text: She represented Peru at the 1972 Summer Olympics and 1976 Summer Olympics.

title: Lauren Wells (athlete)
text: Lauren Wells (née Boden) (born 3 August 1988) is an Australian athletics competitor.

title: Lauren Wells (athlete)
text: Her events are the 400 metre hurdles, 400 metres and long jump.

title: Lauren Wells (athlete)
text: She was the youngest woman to win the 400 metres hurdle event at the Australian national championships.

title: Lauren Wells (athlete)
text: She has competed in the long jump event and the 400 metres hurdle event at the World University Games.

title: Lauren Wells (athlete)
text: She has competed at the 2006 and 2010 Commonwealth Games and the 2012 and 2016 Summer Olympics in the 400 metre hurdles event.

title: Deby LaPlante
text: Deborah C. "Deby" LaPlante (, in second marriage Smith; born April 3, 1953) is a retired female track and field athlete from the United States, who competed in the hurdles event.

title: Deby LaPlante
text: She twice won a medal at the Pan American Games during her career.

title: Deby LaPlante
text: LaPlante set her personal best in the women's 100m hurdles event on June 16, 1979, clocking 12.86 in Walnut, California.

title: Jo Ann Terry
text: Jo Ann Terry-Grissom (born August 4, 1938 in Indianapolis, Indiana) is a retired female hurdler from the United States, who represented her native country at two consecutive Summer Olympics, starting in 1960.

title: Jo Ann Terry
text: Affiliated with the Tennessee State University she won the 80 m hurdles event at the 1963 Pan American Games.

title: 1963 Pan American Games
text: The 4th Pan American Games were held from April 20 to May 5, 1963, in São Paulo, Brazil.

title: List of songs recorded by Goldfrapp
text: English electronic music duo Goldfrapp have recorded songs for five studio albums, one compilation album and guest features.

title: List of songs recorded by Goldfrapp
text: After signing a contract with record label Mute Records in August 1999, Goldfrapp began to work on their debut studio album, "Felt Mountain", which was released in 2000.

title: List of songs recorded by Goldfrapp
text: Alison Goldfrapp and Will Gregory wrote almost all of its songs, and would continue to do so for their later albums.

title: List of songs recorded by Goldfrapp
text: The album's only collaboration was with Tim Norfolk and Bob Locke of the band Startled Insects on the album's third single "Human".

title: List of songs recorded by Goldfrapp
text: The following year, Goldfrapp collaborated with Adrian Utley on the song "End Titles" for the "Accelerator" soundtrack.

title: Anymore (Goldfrapp song)
text: "Anymore" is a song performed by English group Goldfrapp from their seventh studio album "Silver Eye" (2017).

title: Anymore (Goldfrapp song)
text: It was released as a CD single and digital download on 23 January 2017 through Mute Records.

title: Anymore (Goldfrapp song)
text: The song was written and produced by Alison Goldfrapp and William Owen Gregory, with additional production coming from The Haxan Cloak and John Congleton.

title: Anymore (Goldfrapp song)
text: The song incorporates several genres, including dance-pop, electronica and synth-pop, and takes influence from disco and glitch music.

title: Anymore (Goldfrapp song)
text: Critics noticed similarities between "Anymore" and the music from their 2003 album "Black Cherry".

title: Anymore (Goldfrapp song)
text: Lyrically, Goldfrapp sings in robotic vocals about romance, which one critic felt referenced their 2005 single "Ooh La La".

title: Alive (Goldfrapp song)
text: "Alive" is a song by English electronic music duo Goldfrapp from their fifth studio album, "Head First" (2010).

title: Alive (Goldfrapp song)
text: It was written and produced by Alison Goldfrapp and Will Gregory, with additional production by Richard X.

title: Alive (Goldfrapp song)
text: The song was released on 7 June 2010 as the album's second single.

title: Alive (Goldfrapp song)
text: The single failed to chart on the UK Singles Chart, while becoming Goldfrapp's fifth single to top the Hot Dance Club Songs chart in the United States.

title: Pearl Lowe
text: Pearl Lowe (born Pearl Samantha Davis; 1970), is an English fashion and textiles designer, and former singer-songwriter.

title: Alison Goldfrapp
text: Alison Elizabeth Margaret Goldfrapp (born 13 May 1966) is an English musician and record producer, best known as the lead vocalist of the electronic music duo Goldfrapp.

title: Ocean (Goldfrapp song)
text: "Ocean" is a song by English group Goldfrapp from their seventh studio album "Silver Eye" (2017).

title: Ocean (Goldfrapp song)
text: It was released as the album's first promotional single on 10 March 2017 through Mute Records.

title: Ocean (Goldfrapp song)
text: The song was written and produced by Alison Goldfrapp and William Owen Gregory, with additional production coming from The Haxan Cloak and John Congleton.

title: Ocean (Goldfrapp song)
text: An electronic and synth-rock song, "Ocean" marks the return of Goldfrapp's heavy use of synths in their music.

title: Ocean (Goldfrapp song)
text: Written in couplets, the lyrics were described as dark by several commentators.

title: Train (Goldfrapp song)
text: "Train" is an electronic dance song written by British group Goldfrapp for their second album "Black Cherry" (2003).

title: Train (Goldfrapp song)
text: The song was produced by Goldfrapp and received a very positive reception from music critics.

title: Train (Goldfrapp song)
text: It was released as the lead single in the second quarter of 2003 and reached the top thirty in the United Kingdom, where it became Goldfrapp's first top thirty single.

title: Train (Goldfrapp song)
text: The original title of the song was "Wolf Lady", which makes reference to the lyrics in the second verse of the song.

title: Train (Goldfrapp song)
text: The lyrics of "Train" are based on Alison Goldfrapp's observations while in Los Angeles, California.

title: Train (Goldfrapp song)
text: She stated that the song describes wealth, drugs, and sex with "a sort of disgust of it and at the same time a sort of need to indulge in these things."

title: Strict Machine
text: "Strict Machine" is an electronic dance song written by British group Goldfrapp and Nick Batt for their second studio album "Black Cherry" (2003).

title: Strict Machine
text: It was produced by Goldfrapp and describes laboratory rats in neuroscience experiments.

title: Strict Machine
text: Alison Goldfrapp read in a newspaper about experiments in which scientists stimulated rats' brains so that the rats would feel joy when following commands.

title: Strict Machine
text: She was inspired to write "Strict Machine" based on images of the experiment and "more human aspects of machines and sex and control."

title: Ride a White Horse
text: "Ride a White Horse" is a song performed by English electronic music duo Goldfrapp.

title: Ride a White Horse
text: The song was written by Alison Goldfrapp, Will Gregory and Nick Batt for Goldfrapp's third album "Supernature" (2005).

title: Ride a White Horse
text: The song was inspired by the disco era nightclub Studio 54.

title: Seventh Tree
text: Seventh Tree is the fourth studio album by English electronic music duo Goldfrapp, released on 22 February 2008 by Mute Records.

title: Seventh Tree
text: It was named after a dream Alison Goldfrapp had about a "very large tree".

title: Seventh Tree
text: Taking inspiration from paganism and surreal English children's books, Goldfrapp described the album as a "sensual counterpoint to the glitterball glamour of "Supernature"", their previous studio album from 2005.

title: Matheson & Company
text: Matheson & Company was a London-based trading house closely associated with Jardine Matheson of Hong Kong and Jardine Skinner of Calcutta.

title: Matheson & Company
text: It arranged finance and handled imports from those two companies of products such as tea, silk and jute.

title: Matheson & Company
text: Matheson & Company also became involved in venture-capital, specializing in mining.

title: Matheson & Company
text: The company was a member of the consortium that formed the Rio Tinto Company.

title: Matheson & Company
text: After 1912 it became a subsidiary of Jardine Matheson.

title: Robert Thom (translator)
text: Robert Thom (; 1807 – 14 September 1846) was an English nineteenth century Chinese language translator and diplomat based in Canton (modern day Guangzhou) who worked for the trading house Jardine, Matheson & Co. and was seconded to the British armed forces during the First Opium War (1839 – 1842).

title: British Central Africa Company
text: The British Central Africa Company Ltd was one of the four largest European-owned companies that operated in colonial Nyasaland, now Malawi.

title: British Central Africa Company
text: The company was incorporated in 1902 to acquire the business interests that Eugene Sharrer, an early settler and entrepreneur, had developed in the British Central Africa Protectorate.

title: British Central Africa Company
text: Sharrer became the majority shareholder of the company on its foundation.

title: British Central Africa Company
text: The company initially had trading and transport interests, but these were sold by the 1930s.

title: British Central Africa Company
text: For most of the colonial period, its extensive estates produced cotton, tobacco or tea but the British Central Africa Company Ltd developed the reputation of being a harsh and exploitative landlord whose relations with its tenants were poor.

title: British Central Africa Company
text: In 1962, shortly before independence, the company sold most of its undeveloped land to the Nyasaland government, but it retained some plantations and two tea factories.

title: British Central Africa Company
text: It changed its name to The Central Africa Company Ltd and was acquired by the Lonrho group, both in 1964.

title: Eugene Sharrer
text: Eugene Charles Albert Sharrer was a British subject by naturalisation but of German descent, who was a leading entrepreneur in what is now Malawi for around fifteen years between his arrival in 1888 and his departure.

title: Eugene Sharrer
text: He rapidly built-up commercial operations including wholesale and retail trading, considerable holdings of land, cotton and coffee plantations and a fleet of steamers on the Zambezi and Shire rivers.

title: Eugene Sharrer
text: Sharrer was prominent in pressure groups that represented the interests of European planters and their businesses to the colonial authorities, and was responsible for the development of the first railway in what had become the British Central Africa Protectorate, whose construction was agreed in 1902.

title: Eugene Sharrer
text: In 1902, Sharrer consolidate all his business interests into the British Central Africa Company Ltd and became its principal shareholder Shortly after this he left British Central Africa permanently for London, although he retained his financial interests in the territory.

title: Eugene Sharrer
text: Very little is known of his history before he arrived in Central Africa but he died in London during the First World War.

title: Prediction Company
text: Prediction Company was founded in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, in March 1991 by J. Doyne Farmer, Norman Packard and James McGill.

title: Prediction Company
text: The company uses forecasting techniques to build black-box trading systems for financial markets, mainly employing statistical learning theory.

title: Prediction Company
text: In September 1992, Prediction Company entered into an exclusive contract with O'Connor and Associates, a Chicago derivatives trading house, to provide investment advice and technology.

title: Prediction Company
text: Soon after O'Connor merged with Swiss Bank Corporation, which later merged with Union Bank of Switzerland (UBS).

title: Prediction Company
text: Prediction Company's contract was renewed multiple times and in 2005 UBS purchased Prediction Company outright.

title: Prediction Company
text: After being a wholly owned subsidiary of UBS, Prediction Company was acquired in 2013 by an affiliate of Millennium Partners, L.P.

title: J. & N. Philips
text: J. & N. Philips and Company was a business established in 1747 by members of the Philips family, and which ceased trading in 1970.

title: J. & N. Philips
text: Originally based in Tean, Staffordshire, England, the business was a manufacturer of textile products that expanded both by organic growth and by taking over other businesses involved in the manufacture and merchanting of textile products and smallware.

title: J. & N. Philips
text: It formed a part of a network of companies operated by the family, whose business interests came to include manufacture of hats and textiles such as linen smallwares, silks and fustians, as well as cotton spinning and dealing, power loom weaving, export merchanting and general warehousing.

title: J. & N. Philips
text: The family was also involved in politics, with George Philips, Mark Philips and Robert Needham Philips all being Members of Parliament and all promoting the ideals of Manchesterism while in office.

title: J. & N. Philips
text: George's son, George Richard Philips, was also a member of the House of Commons.

title: Jardine Matheson
text: Jardine Matheson Holdings Limited, also known as Jardines, is a British conglomerate incorporated in Bermuda, with its primary listing on the Singapore Exchange.

title: Jardine Matheson
text: The majority of its business interests are in Asia, and its subsidiaries include Jardine Pacific, Jardine Motors, Jardine Lloyd Thompson, Hongkong Land, Jardine Strategic Holdings, Dairy Farm, Mandarin Oriental Hotel Group, Jardine Cycle & Carriage and Astra International.

title: David Sheepshanks
text: David Richard Sheepshanks CBE DL is the founding and current Chairman of the St George's Park National Football Centre and former Chairman of Ipswich Town FC.

title: David Sheepshanks
text: He is also chairman of UK Community Foundations (UKCF), the umbrella organisation for all community foundations in the UK, providing philanthropic advice to clients and delivering UK-wide grant-making programmes.

title: David Sheepshanks
text: Other business interests include non Executive roles with Coutts Bank, 21st Club and Onside Law.

title: David Sheepshanks
text: Past business interests included Starfish Ltd 1980-1990 and Suffolk Foods Ltd which he founded in 1990 with his brother Rick and where he was Chairman and a majority shareholder before selling in 2004.

title: David Sheepshanks
text: He also served externally on various local radio station Boards including Chairman of VIBE FM in 1990 and Director of Radio Orwell and BBC Radio Suffolk Advisory Board.

title: London Penny Post
text: The London Penny Post was a premier postal system whose function was to deliver mail within London and its immediate suburbs for the modest sum of one penny.

title: London Penny Post
text: The Penny Post was established in 1680 by William Dockwra and his business partner, Robert Murray.

title: London Penny Post
text: Dockwra was a merchant and a member of the Armourer and Brasiers Livery Company and was appointed a Customs Under-Searcher for the Port of London in 1663.

title: London Penny Post
text: Murray would later become clerk in the excise office of the Penny Post.

title: London Penny Post
text: The London Penny Post mail service was launched with weeks of publicity preceding it on 27 March 1680.

title: London Penny Post
text: The new London Penny Post provided the city of London with a much needed inter-city mail delivery system.

title: London Penny Post
text: The new Penny Post was influential in establishing a model system and pattern for the various Provincial English Penny Posts in the years that followed.

title: London Penny Post
text: It was the first postal system to use hand-stamps to postmark the mail to indicate the place and time of the mailing and that its postage had been prepaid.

title: London Penny Post
text: The success of the Penny Post would also threaten the interests of the Duke of York who profited directly from the existing general post office.

title: London Penny Post
text: It also compromised the business interests of porters and private couriers.

title: London Penny Post
text: The Penny Post was also involved in publishing various criticisms towards the British monarchy, the Duke of York in particular, which ultimately led to the take over of the Penny Post by crown authorities.

title: London Penny Post
text: The earliest known Penny Post postmark is dated 13 December 1680 and is considered by some to be the world's first postage 'stamp'.

title: Bonyic Dam
text: The Bonyic Dam is a gravity dam on the Bonyic River, a tributary of the Teribe River about 24 km southwest of Changuinola in the Bocas del Toro province of northwestern Panama.

title: Bonyic Dam
text: The project produce hydroelectricity at a 32.64 MW power station about 3.8 km downstream of the dam.

title: Bonyic Dam
text: The builder and operator is Hidroécología Teribe (HET) S.A., a private Panamanian company whose majority stockholder is Empresas Públicas de Medellín (EPM), a public utility company owned by the municipal government of Medellín, Colombia.

title: Bonyic Dam
text: The dam construction was subject to controversies that have resulted in the removal of its funding by the Inter-American Development Bank.

title: Bonyic Dam
text: The Bonyic dam would obstruct access for migrating fish to La Amistad International Park.

title: Bonyic Dam
text: Members of the local indigenous people, the Naso, have periodically blockaded the single road to delay construction for a cumulative total of four years.

title: Imi Lichtenfeld
text: Emrich "Imi" Lichtenfeld (May 26, 1910 – January 9, 1998) was a Hungarian-born Israeli martial artist who founded the Krav Maga self-defense system.

title: Imi Lichtenfeld
text: He was also known as Imi Sde-Or, the Hebrew calque of his surname.

title: AIL M325 Command Car
text: The AIL M325 Command Car is a 4x4 military truck produced by the Automotive Industries Limited (AIL) of Nazareth in Israel from 1970 to 1993 for use by the Israel Defense Forces.

title: AIL M325 Command Car
text: The M325 is a light, versatile truck designed for carrying up to 12 troops and radio equipment while being fitted with up to four 7.62 mm machine guns.

title: AIL M325 Command Car
text: Mechanically, it is based on the Dodge Power Wagon, which it succeeded in service for the Israel Defense Forces.

title: IDF Caterpillar D9
text: The Israeli Armored CAT D9—nicknamed "Doobi" (Hebrew: דובי‎ ‎ , for teddy bear)—is a Caterpillar D9 armored bulldozer that was modified by the Israel Defense Forces, Israeli Military Industries and Israel Aerospace Industries to increase the survivability of the bulldozer in hostile environments and enable it to withstand heavy attacks, thus making it suitable for military combat engineering use.

title: IDF Caterpillar D9
text: The IDF Caterpillar D9 is operated by the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) Combat Engineering Corps for combat engineering and counter-terrorism operations.

title: Krav Maga
text: Krav Maga ( ; Hebrew: קְרַב מַגָּע‎ ] , "lit."

title: Krav Maga
text: "contact-combat") is a military self-defense system developed for the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) and Israeli security forces (Shin Bet and Mossad) that consists of a combination of techniques sourced from Boxing, Wrestling, Aikido, Judo, Karate along with realistic fight training.

title: Krav Maga
text: Krav Maga is known for its focus on real-world situations and its extreme efficiency and brutal counter-attacks.

title: Krav Maga
text: It was derived from the street-fighting experience of Hungarian-Israeli martial artist Imi Lichtenfeld, who made use of his training as a boxer and wrestler as a means of defending the Jewish quarter against fascist groups in Bratislava, Czechoslovakia in the mid-to-late 1930s.

title: Krav Maga
text: In the late 1940s, following his migration to Israel, he began to provide lessons on combat training to what was to become the IDF.

title: Women in the Israel Defense Forces
text: Women in the Israel Defense Forces are female soldiers who serve in the Israel Defense Forces.

title: Women in the Israel Defense Forces
text: Israel is one of only a few countries in the world with a mandatory military service requirement for women.

title: Moshe Kaplinsky
text: Maj. Gen. Moshe Kaplinsky (Hebrew: משה קפלינסקי; born January 20, 1957), was the CEO of Better Place Israel.

title: Moshe Kaplinsky
text: Most recently, he was Deputy Chief of the General Staff of the Israel Defense Forces.

title: Moshe Kaplinsky
text: He was previously head of the Israel Defense Forces's Central Command, whose area of responsibility includes the West Bank.

title: Moshe Kaplinsky
text: As Deputy Chief of the General Staff he was second in command of the Israel Defense Forces.

title: Israel Defense Forces History Museum
text: The Israel Defense Forces History Museum (Hebrew: בתי האוסף‎ ‎ , Batei HaOsef, "lit."

title: Israel Defense Forces History Museum
text: The Collection Houses) is a museum dedicated to the history of Israel's military, from the underground organizations active during the British Mandate for Palestine to the modern Israel Defense Forces.

title: Israel Defense Forces History Museum
text: The museum is located in southern Tel Aviv, next to the Jaffa Railway Station.

title: Israel Defense Forces History Museum
text: There is a TAR-21 present to be examined.

title: Friends of the Israel Defense Forces
text: Friends of the Israel Defense Forces (FIDF) (in Hebrew ארגון ידידי צה״ל בארה״ב) is an organization established in 1981 dedicated to the men and women serving in the Israel Defense Forces (IDF), wounded veterans, and the families of fallen soldiers.

title: Friends of the Israel Defense Forces
text: Headquartered in New York City, Friends of the Israel Defense Forces is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization that operates fifteen regional offices in the United States and Panama.

title: Friends of the Israel Defense Forces
text: Friends of the Israel Defense Forces initiates and supports educational, social, cultural and recreational programs and facilities in an effort to ease the burden that the Israel Defense Forces' soldiers and their families carry on behalf of the Jewish community worldwide.

title: Galgalatz
text: Galgalatz (Hebrew: גלגלצ‎ ‎ ) is a popular Israeli radio station operated by Israel Defense Forces Radio.

title: Galgalatz
text: This is the second of two Israel Defense Forces-operated stations, while the first one is Israel Defense Forces Radio/Galatz.

title: Galgalatz
text: The station was established in 1993 and broadcasts primarily nonstop pop music and traffic reports, and few content programs.

title: Galgalatz
text: The station was established with the aid of the Israeli Ministry of Transportation (the Israeli National Authority for Traffic Safety), and frequently broadcasts Traffic Safety messages.

title: Galgalatz
text: At the top of every hour the station broadcasts a news report.

title: Zvi Zamir
text: Zvi Zamir (Hebrew: צבי זמיר‎ ‎ ) born Zvicka Zarzevsky (born 1925) was a major general in the Israel Defense Forces and the Director of the Mossad from 1968 to 1974.

title: Zvi Zamir
text: Born in Poland, Zamir immigrated with his family to the then British Mandate of Palestine when only seven months old.

title: Zvi Zamir
text: At the age of 18 Zamir began his military career, first as a soldier in the Haganah's Palmach, a unit that included future Israeli leaders among the likes of Moshe Dayan and Yitzhak Rabin.

title: Zvi Zamir
text: During the 1948 Arab–Israeli War, Zamir fought in the newly created Israel Defense Forces.

title: Zvi Zamir
text: After the war he continued climbing the chain of command, eventually promoted to the Commander of the Southern Command.

title: Zvi Zamir
text: His final IDF post before being appointed Mossad Director came in 1966 when he was appointed the military attaché to London.

title: Wheel in the Sky
text: "Wheel in the Sky" is a song by the American rock band Journey, recorded in 1977 and included on their fourth studio album, "Infinity."

title: Wheel in the Sky
text: It was written and composed by Robert Fleischman, Neal Schon and Diane Valory.

title: All Systems Go (Vinnie Vincent Invasion album)
text: All Systems Go is the second and final studio album by American glam metal band Vinnie Vincent Invasion, released on May 17, 1988.

title: All Systems Go (Vinnie Vincent Invasion album)
text: "All Systems Go" featured new vocalist Mark Slaughter, who replaced Robert Fleischman.

title: All Systems Go (Vinnie Vincent Invasion album)
text: The band toured in support for the album, headlining small clubs, but broke up after the completion of the tour at the end of August 1988.

title: All Systems Go (Vinnie Vincent Invasion album)
text: The album features Yngwie Malmsteen's vocalist Jeff Scott Soto on backing vocals.

title: (No Pussyfooting)
text: (No Pussyfooting) is the debut studio album by the British musicians Robert Fripp and Brian Eno (credited as Fripp & Eno).

title: (No Pussyfooting)
text: The album was released in 1973. "

title: (No Pussyfooting)
text: (No Pussyfooting)" was the first of three major collaborations between the musicians, growing out of Eno's early tape recording loop experiments and Fripp's "Frippertronics" electric guitar technique.

title: Trance Spirits
text: Trance Spirits (2002) is the collaborative album by American ambient musicians Steve Roach, Jeffrey Fayman and guest musicians Robert Fripp and Momodou Kah.

title: Jimmy Crespo
text: James Crespo, Jr. (born July 5, 1954 in Brooklyn, New York) is an American guitarist.

title: Jimmy Crespo
text: He was the lead guitarist for Aerosmith from 1979 until 1984.

title: Jimmy Crespo
text: He co-wrote "Rock in a Hard Place" with Steven Tyler, and has performed or recorded with Rod Stewart, Billy Squier, Meat Loaf, Stevie Nicks, Robert Fleischman, Rough Cutt, Renegade, Flame and others.

title: Tin Lids
text: The Tin Lids were an Australian children's pop group formed in 1990 with Eliza-Jane Barnes, Elly-May Barnes, Jackie Barnes and Mahalia Barnes: all on vocals.

title: Tin Lids
text: They are the four offspring of Jimmy Barnes and Jane Mahoney.

title: Tin Lids
text: The group released three albums, "Hey Rudolph!"

title: Tin Lids
text: (November 1991) – which peaked at No. 6 on the ARIA Albums Chart, "Snakes & Ladders" (July 1992) – which was nominated for the ARIA Award for Best Children's Album in 1993, and "Dinosaur Dreaming" (1993).

title: Freight Train Heart
text: Freight Train Heart is the third studio album by Australian rock singer Jimmy Barnes, released in late 1987 in Australia by Mushroom Records and in early 1988 in the United States by Geffen.

title: Freight Train Heart
text: It spent 5 weeks at the top of the Australian Album charts in Dec 1987 / Jan 1988.

title: Freight Train Heart
text: Most of the tracks were written by Barnes and producer Jonathan Cain, however "Waitin' for the Heartache" was co-written by Barnes and Desmond Child and "Walk On" was co-written by Child and ex-Rainbow vocalist Joe Lynn Turner; (Turner would later record his own version with his band Sunstorm).

title: Freight Train Heart
text: Two songs were also written with Jim Vallance.

title: Freight Train Heart
text: According to Vallance, Cain also contributed "later", most likely during the recording process.

title: Robert Fleischman
text: Robert Fleischman (born March 11, 1953) is an American musician, songwriter, and record producer.

title: Jimmy Barnes
text: James Dixon Swan {'1': ", '2': ", '3': ", '4': "} (born 28 April 1956), better known as Jimmy Barnes, is a Scottish-Australian rock singer-songwriter.

title: Jimmy Barnes
text: His career both as a solo performer and as the lead vocalist with the rock band Cold Chisel has made him one of the most popular and best-selling Australian music artists of all time.

title: Jimmy Barnes
text: The combination of 14 Australian Top 40 albums for Cold Chisel and 13 charting solo albums, including nine No. 1s, gives Barnes the highest number of hit albums of any Australian artist.

title: Michael Lee (musician)
text: Michael Lee (19 November 1969 – 24 November 2008) was an English drummer who toured and recorded with former Led Zeppelin musicians Robert Plant and Jimmy Page.

title: Emerson Electric
text: The Emerson Electric Company () is an American multinational corporation headquartered in Ferguson, Missouri, United States.

title: Emerson Electric
text: This Fortune 500 company manufactures products and provides engineering services for a wide range of industrial, commercial, and consumer markets.

title: Computer Sciences Corporation
text: Computer Sciences Corporation (CSC) was an American multinational corporation that provided information technology (IT) services and professional services.

title: Computer Sciences Corporation
text: On April 3, 2017, it merged with HP Enterprise Services to create DXC Technology.

title: ManpowerGroup
text: ManpowerGroup (formerly known as Manpower Inc.) is a Fortune 500 American multinational corporation headquartered in Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

title: ManpowerGroup
text: Founded in 1948 by Elmer Winter and Aaron Scheinfeld, ManpowerGroup is the third-largest staffing firm in the world behind Swiss firm Adecco and Dutch firm Randstad.

title: ManpowerGroup
text: The company provides administrative & support services, professional services, and business services through its four primary brands: Manpower (contingent staffing & permanent recruitment), Experis (professional resourcing and project-based solutions), Right Management (career management, workforce consulting, and training & development), and ManpowerGroup Solutions (managed services and outsourcing).

title: Sykes Enterprises
text: Sykes Enterprises, Incorporated (stylized as SYKES) is an American multinational corporation headquartered in Tampa, Florida.

title: Sykes Enterprises
text: The company provides business process outsourcing services, IT consulting and IT-enabled services, such as technical support and customer service.

title: Cognizant
text: Cognizant is an American multinational corporation that provides IT services, including digital, technology, consulting, and operations services.

title: Cognizant
text: It is headquartered in Teaneck, New Jersey, United States.

title: Cognizant
text: Cognizant is listed in the NASDAQ-100 and the S&P 500 indices.

title: Cognizant
text: It was founded as an in-house technology unit of Dun & Bradstreet in 1994, and started serving external clients in 1996.

title: Active Network, LLC
text: Active Network, LLC, is an American multinational corporation headquartered in Dallas, Texas, that provides software as a service for activity and participant management.

title: Active Network, LLC
text: Active's management software supports a range of clients including: races, recreation, outdoor activities, camps, churches, golf courses, sports, schools, skiing services and attractions.

title: Verifone
text: Verifone is an American multinational corporation headquartered in San Jose, California that provides technology for electronic payment transactions and value-added services at the point-of-sale.

title: Flowserve
text: The Flowserve Corporation is an American multinational corporation and one of the largest suppliers of industrial and environmental machinery such as pumps, valves, end face mechanical seals, automation, and services to the power, oil, gas, chemical and other industries.

title: Flowserve
text: Headquartered in Irving, Texas, which is a suburb of Dallas, Texas, Flowserve has over 19,000 employees in more than 60 countries.

title: Flowserve
text: Flowserve sells products and offers aftermarket services to engineering and construction firms, original equipment manufacturers, distributors and end users.

title: Flowserve
text: The Flowserve brand name originated in 1997 with a merger of BW/IP and Durco International.

title: Dell EMC
text: Dell EMC (EMC Corporation until 2016) is an American multinational corporation headquartered in Hopkinton, Massachusetts, United States.

title: Dell EMC
text: Dell EMC sells data storage, information security, virtualization, analytics, cloud computing and other products and services that enable organizations to store, manage, protect, and analyze data.

title: Dell EMC
text: Dell EMC's target markets include large companies and small- and medium-sized businesses across various vertical markets.

title: Dell EMC
text: The company's stock (as EMC Corporation) was added to the New York Stock Exchange on April 6, 1986, and was also listed on the S&P 500 index.

title: Mirabeau (company)
text: Mirabeau B.V. is a digital agency headquartered in Amsterdam, Netherlands.

title: Mirabeau (company)
text: Mirabeau has offices also in Eindhoven, and Rotterdam — both in the Netherlands — Paris, and Guangzhou.

title: Mirabeau (company)
text: It employs about 300 people.

title: Mirabeau (company)
text: The company was acquired by Cognizant in 2016.

title: Darrel Chaney
text: Darrel Lee Chaney (born March 9, 1948, in Hammond, Indiana) is an American former player/announcer in Major League Baseball who played for the Cincinnati Reds and Atlanta Braves from 1969 to 1979.

title: Darrel Chaney
text: In the early 1980s he worked for the Braves as an announcer along with Ernie Johnson, Skip Caray and Pete Van Wieren.

title: Darrel Chaney
text: He was on the Atlanta Braves Radio Network as well as WTBS-TV.

title: Abraham's family tree
text: Abraham is known as the patriarch of the Jewish people through Isaac, the son born to him and Sarah in their old age and the patriarch of Islam through his son Ishmael, born to Abraham and his wife’s servant Hagar.

title: The Minotaur in House of Leaves
text: The Minotaur or Minotauros was the son born of lust to Queen Pasiphae of Crete and a bull.

title: The Minotaur in House of Leaves
text: He had the body of a man and the head of a bull and was more beast than human.

title: The Minotaur in House of Leaves
text: The creature was banished by King Minos to reside in the centre of a labyrinth in Knossos built by the ingenious architect Daedalus and his son Icarus.

title: The Minotaur in House of Leaves
text: The Minotaur was nursed by Queen Pasiphae as a child but grew to devour humans, so he was safely put away in the maze contrived so carefully and trickily that it was impossible for anyone that entered to navigate or escape it.

title: The Minotaur in House of Leaves
text: The Athenians were forced to pay a tribute to King Minos by sacrificing seven of their maidens and seven of their men, unarmed, to the Minotaur every nine years.

title: The Minotaur in House of Leaves
text: The Minotaur eventually fell prey to the sword of Theseus.

title: The Minotaur in House of Leaves
text: It is also rumoured that the Minotaur was in fact the offspring of King Minos but his unsightly and grotesque appearance was shameful to King Minos and was the reason why the Minotaur was banished under the pretext of inspiring fear and cannibalistic capabilities.

title: Sunsum
text: In the mythology of the Ashanti people and Akan people, the Sunsum is one's Spirit.

title: Sunsum
text: The Sunsum is what connects the body (honam) to the soul (Kra).

title: Sunsum
text: The Sunsum can be transmitted in a variety of ways, including from father to son during conception.

title: Sunsum
text: This power is used to protect the carriers of this spirit.

title: Sunsum
text: When a man dies, the Sunsum returns to the metaphorical house of the father in wait to be reincarnated in the next son born of the men of that family.

title: Mithridates IV of Parthia
text: Mithridates IV of Parthia (flourished 1st century & 2nd century) was a Prince of Iranian and Greek ancestry.

title: Mithridates IV of Parthia
text: He ruled as King of the Parthian Empire from 129 to 140.

title: Mithridates IV of Parthia
text: Mithridates IV was the youngest son born to Vonones II from a Greek concubine and was one of the brothers of Osroes I of Parthia (109–129).

title: Mithridates IV of Parthia
text: During the invasion of Mesopotamia by the Roman emperor Trajan (98–117) in 116, he and his son Sanatruces II of Parthia, took up the diadem but were defeated.

title: Mithridates IV of Parthia
text: After the death of Osroes I in 129 he assumed the throne and continued the struggle with the rival King Vologases III of Parthia (105–147).

title: Mithridates IV of Parthia
text: He died in an attack on Commagene in 140.

title: Mithridates IV of Parthia
text: Mithridates IV had appointed his son Sanatruces II as his successor, but Sanatruces II fell in a battle with the Romans.

title: Mithridates IV of Parthia
text: Another son, Vologases IV of Parthia (147–191), took the throne after the death of Vologases III in 147.

title: James Chaney
text: James Earl Chaney (May 30, 1943 – June 21, 1964), from Meridian, Mississippi, was one of three American civil rights workers who were murdered during Freedom Summer by members of the Ku Klux Klan near Philadelphia, Mississippi.

title: James Chaney
text: The others were Andrew Goodman and Michael Schwerner from New York City.

title: Nijō Kanemoto
text: Nijō Kanemoto (二条 兼基 , 1268–1334) , son of regent Nijō Yoshizane and adopted son of Nijō Morotada, was a Japanese "kugyō" (court noble) of the Kamakura period (1185–1333) of Japan.

title: Nijō Kanemoto
text: He held regent positions sesshō in 1298 and kampaku from 1300 to 1305.

title: Nijō Kanemoto
text: Regent Nijō Michihira was his son born by a concubine.

title: Nijō Kanemoto
text: His wife was a daughter of regent Kujō Tadanori; she gave birth to a son who was adopted by Imakōji family and became known as Imakōji Yoshifuyu, and a daughter who later married Kujō Fusazane.

title: Savarni Manu
text: According to Hindu mythology, there are 14 Manus specified.

title: Savarni Manu
text: As per Hindu texts present Manvantara runs on the name of seventh Manu i.e. Vaivasvata Manu.

title: Savarni Manu
text: Next coming Manu i.e. eighth Manu name is Savarni Manu or Surya Savarnika Manu.

title: Savarni Manu
text: Surya Savarnika means resemblance of Sun.

title: Savarni Manu
text: He is the son born to the sun-god Surya and wife named Chhaya.

title: Savarni Manu
text: Savarni's sons would be headed by Nirmoka, and among the demigods are the Sutapas.

title: Savarni Manu
text: Bali, the son of Virochana, is Indra, and Galava and Parashurama are among the seven sages.

title: Savarni Manu
text: In this age of Manu, the incarnation of the Supreme Personality of Godhead appears as Sarvabhauma, the son of Devaguhya and Sarasvati.

title: Savarni Manu
text: On the name of this Manu the only Ashram i.e. S S M Ashramam i.e Surya Savarnika Manavu Ashramam has been established at Garlavoddu, in India.

title: Payne baronets
text: The Payne Baronetcy, of St Christopher's in the West Indies, was a title in the Baronetage of Great Britain.

title: Payne baronets
text: It was created on 31 October 1737 for Charles Payne.

title: Payne baronets
text: According to some sources that title became extinct on the death of the second Baronet, Sir Gillis Payne, in 1801.

title: Payne baronets
text: Sir Gillis was in a relationship with a farmer's daughter, Maria Keeling.

title: Payne baronets
text: They apparently married in 1761 although several children had been born before this date.

title: Payne baronets
text: Peter Payne was the eldest son born after the marriage and would normally have succeeded in the title.

title: Payne baronets
text: However, he allowed his eldest brother John Payne to assume the title, although John was illegitimate.

title: Payne baronets
text: John died in 1803 when his son Charles assumed the title.

title: Payne baronets
text: However, in 1828 Peter Payne raised the question in the courts over who was the rightful baronet.

title: Payne baronets
text: The Court of Chancery declared that he was the rightful heir to his father, but this was overturned by the Lord Chancellor in 1829.

title: Payne baronets
text: Nonetheless, during his lifetime Sir Peter was universally acknowledged as a baronet.

title: Payne baronets
text: Most reference books on the British nobility and baronetage include the title, although they describe it as being in dispute between rival branches of the family.

title: Payne baronets
text: Charles Robert Salusbury Payne, the supposed sixth Baronet, appears to have discontinued the claim around 1900.

title: Fannie Lee Chaney
text: Fannie Lee Chaney (September 4, 1921 – May 22, 2007) was an American baker turned civil rights activist after her son James Chaney was murdered by the Ku Klux Klan during the 1964 Freedom Summer rides in Mississippi.

title: Conrad Black
text: Conrad Moffat Black, Lord Black of Crossharbour, KSG (born 25 August 1944) is a Canadian-born British former newspaper publisher and author.

title: Conrad Black
text: He is a non-affiliated life peer.

title: RAF Bomber Command Memorial
text: The Royal Air Force Bomber Command Memorial is a memorial in Green Park, London, commemorating the crews of RAF Bomber Command who embarked on missions during the Second World War.

title: RAF Bomber Command Memorial
text: The memorial, located on Piccadilly near Hyde Park Corner, was built to mark the sacrifice of 55,573 aircrew from Britain, Canada, Czechoslovakia, Poland and other countries of the Commonwealth, as well as civilians of all nations killed during raids.

title: Canada Memorial
text: The Canada Memorial in Green Park, London, United Kingdom, commemorates members of the Canadian Forces killed during the First and Second World Wars.

title: Canada Memorial
text: It was designed by the Canadian sculptor Pierre Granche, erected in 1992 and unveiled by Queen Elizabeth II in 1994.

title: Canada Memorial
text: The memorial was the result of lobbying and fund raising, much of it in Canada, by the former Canadian media tycoon Conrad Black.

title: Cenotaph War Memorial, Colombo
text: The Cenotaph War Memorial in Viharamahadevi Park, Colombo, Sri Lanka is dedicated to the military personal from Ceylon killed in action during the two world wars.

title: Cenotaph War Memorial, Colombo
text: It comprises a towering Cenotaph and Memorial Walls.

title: Cenotaph War Memorial, Colombo
text: The foundation stone was laid by Brigadier General Sir William Henry Manning, Governor of Ceylon on December 7, 1921 and was unveiled by him October 27, 1923 at the Galle Face Green and was known as the Victory tower.

title: Cenotaph War Memorial, Colombo
text: It was dismantled and re-erected at Victoria Park, during World War II after fears that the Japanese might use it as a marker to direct their artillery.

title: Cenotaph War Memorial, Colombo
text: The Cenotaph contains the names of those killed in the Great War, while the Memorial Wall behind it maintains the names of those killed in the Second World War.

title: Cenotaph War Memorial, Colombo
text: A single woman, Miss L. Midwood is listed among the dead of the Great war.

title: African and Caribbean War Memorial
text: The African and Caribbean War Memorial in Brixton, London, is the United Kingdom's national memorial to African and Caribbean service personnel who fought in the First and Second World Wars.

title: African and Caribbean War Memorial
text: It originated with a project for a memorial to Caribbean Royal Air Force veterans of World War II who arrived in Britain in 1948 on the MV "Empire Windrush"; this was an extension of the commemorative plaque and sculpture scheme run by the Nubian Jak Community Trust to highlight the historic contributions of Black and minority ethnic people in Britain.

title: African and Caribbean War Memorial
text: The memorial was originally to have been placed at Tilbury Docks, as part of the commemoration for the centenary of the outbreak of World War I. However, as the project began to evolve into a larger tribute that included both World Wars and commemorated servicemen and women from both Africa and the Caribbean, it was agreed by the memorial recipient – the Port of Tilbury – and the project organisers that a new, more accessible location needed to found.

title: African and Caribbean War Memorial
text: The memorial was ultimately permanently installed and unveiled on 22 June 2017 in Windrush Square, Brixton.

title: Peacekeeper Park
text: Peacekeeper Park is an urban park in Calgary, Alberta.

title: Peacekeeper Park
text: The park is located in the neighbourhood of North Glenmore, on the former grounds of Canadian Forces Base Calgary.

title: Peacekeeper Park
text: The park includes a memorial wall with the names of Canadian Forces members who have given their lives on peacekeeping and peace support missions with the United Nations, NATO and other organizations since the end of the Second World War, including the current mission in Afghanistan.

title: Portsmouth Naval Memorial
text: The Portsmouth Naval Memorial, sometimes known as Southsea Naval Memorial, is a war memorial in Portsmouth, Hampshire, England, on Southsea Common beside Clarence Esplanade, between Clarence Pier and Southsea Castle.

title: Portsmouth Naval Memorial
text: The memorial commemorates approximately 25,000 British and Commonwealth sailors who were lost in the World Wars, around 10,000 sailors in the First World War and 15,000 in the Second World War.

title: Portsmouth Naval Memorial
text: The memorial features a central obelisk, with names of the dead on bronze plaques arranged around the memorial according to the year of death.

title: CFB London
text: Canadian Forces Base London (also CFB London) is a former Canadian Forces Base that was located in London, Ontario, Canada.

title: CFB London
text: It was downsized and closed during defence budget cutbacks in the 1990s.

title: CFB London
text: Local Primary Reserve units were supported by Area Support Unit (ASU) London which was located in some of the remaining base buildings, but they are now supported by ASU Toronto.

title: CFB London
text: Much of this support is delivered by a Technical Services Platoon which remains stationed in London.

title: Armed Forces Memorial
text: The Armed Forces Memorial is a national memorial in the United Kingdom, dedicated to the 16,000 servicemen and women of the British Armed Forces killed on duty or through terrorist action since after the Second World War.

title: Armed Forces Memorial
text: It is within the National Memorial Arboretum in Staffordshire.

title: Parliamentary War Memorial
text: The Parliamentary War Memorial, also known as the Recording Angel Memorial, is a stone sculpture in Westminster Hall, unveiled in 1922, which commemorates the members of both Houses of Parliament of the United Kingdom who died in the First World War.

title: Parliamentary War Memorial
text: It names 22 members of the House of Commons, 20 members of the House of Lords, and 9 senior members of staff, together with another 94 sons of members and officers of the House of Commons, who lost their lives in the war.

title: Parliamentary War Memorial
text: (Sons of peers and of officers of the House of Lords are commemorated on the wooden panels of the House of Lords War Memorial in the Royal Gallery.)

title: Parliamentary War Memorial
text: Above the memorial is a large stained glass window which commemorates members and staff of both Houses who died in the Second World War.

title: WNP-1 and WNP-4
text: Washington Nuclear Project Nos. 1 and 4, abbreviated as WNP-1 and WNP-4 were two of the five nuclear power plants on which construction was started by the Washington Public Power Supply System (WPPSS) in order to meet projected electricity demand in the Pacific Northwest.

title: WNP-1 and WNP-4
text: WNP-1, WNP-2 and WNP-3 were part of the original 1968 plan, with WNP-4 (a twin to WNP-1 and located at the same site) and WNP-5 (a twin to WNP-3, in similar fashion) added in the early 1970s.

title: Railway Express Agency Building
text: The Railway Express Agency Building was a historic building located at 1804 Western Avenue in Mattoon, Illinois.

title: Railway Express Agency Building
text: The building was constructed in 1918 to serve as the Mattoon office of the Railway Express Agency.

title: Railway Express Agency Building
text: The Railway Express Agency provided rail express shipping services to Mattoon's citizens, allowing them to ship money and packages along Mattoon's two major railways, the Illinois Central Railroad and Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis (Big Four).

title: Railway Express Agency Building
text: The agency formed in 1917, when the federal government ordered that all existing express services consolidate into a single service; this measure ensured consistent shipping of goods during World War I.

title: Railway Express Agency Building
text: The agency shipped goods to and from Mattoon until 1964, when the Big Four went bankrupt; the building served as a freight depot until 1971.

title: WNP-3 and WNP-5
text: Washington Nuclear Project Nos. 3 and 5, abbreviated as WNP-3 and WNP-5 (collectively known as the Satsop Nuclear Power Plant) were two of the five nuclear power plants on which construction was started by the Washington Public Power Supply System (WPPSS) in order to meet projected electricity demand in the Pacific Northwest.

title: WNP-3 and WNP-5
text: WNP-1, WNP-2 and WNP-3 were part of the original 1968 plan, with WNP-4 (a twin to WNP-1 and located at the same site) and WNP-5 (a twin to WNP-3, in similar fashion) added in the early 1970s.

title: Energy Northwest
text: Energy Northwest (formerly Washington Public Power Supply System) is a United States public power joint operating agency formed by State law in 1957 to produce at-cost power for Northwest utilities.

title: Energy Northwest
text: Headquartered in Richland, Washington, the WPPSS became commonly known as "Whoops" due to over-commitment to nuclear power in the 1970s which brought about financial collapse and the second largest municipal bond default in U.S. history.

title: Energy Northwest
text: WPPSS was renamed Energy Northwest in November 1998.

title: Energy Northwest
text: Agency membership includes 28 public power utilities, including 23 of the state’s 24 public utility districts.

title: Road Safety Authority
text: The Road Safety Authority (Irish: "Údarás Um Shábháilteacht Ar Bhóithre" ) or RSA, is a state agency formed by the Irish Government to promote road safety.

title: Road Safety Authority
text: The agency has devolved control of much of the work of the Department of Transport.

title: Anti-Corruption Commission Seychelles
text: The Anti-Corruption Commission Seychelles (abbreviated ACCS) is an independent Seychellois government agency formed under the Anti-Corruption Act 2016.

title: Anti-Corruption Commission Seychelles
text: Formed in March 2016 after the National Assembly enacted the "Anti-Corruption Law No. 6 of 2016", the agency is charged with receiving complaints, investigating, detecting and preventing corruption-related practices in Seychelles.

title: Extraordinary State Commission
text: The Extraordinary State Commission was a Soviet government agency formed by the Council of People's Commissars on 2 November 1942, by a decree of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet.

title: Extraordinary State Commission
text: It was tasked with investigating World War II crimes against the Soviet Union and collecting documentation which would confirm material losses caused by Nazi Germany.

title: Extraordinary State Commission
text: Its full ceremonial name was: ""Extraordinary State Commission for Ascertaining and Investigating Crimes Perpetrated by the German-Fascist Invaders and their Accomplices"" (Russian: Чрезвычайная Государственная Комиссия , ChGK).

title: Extraordinary State Commission
text: The official aim of this agency included "punishing for the crimes of the German–fascist aggressors."

title: Extraordinary State Commission
text: According to its own data, 32,000 organization staff took part in the work of ChGK and around 7,000,000 Soviet citizens had participated in the collection of materials and evidence.

title: Director General of the European Space Agency
text: The Director General of the European Space Agency is the highest-ranked official of the European Space Agency (ESA), a space agency formed by the collaboration of prominent European nations.

title: WorkCover Authority of New South Wales
text: The WorkCover Authority of New South Wales or WorkCover NSW is a New South Wales Government agency established in 1989.

title: WorkCover Authority of New South Wales
text: The agency creates regulations to promote productive, healthy and safe workplaces for workers and employers in New South Wales.

title: WorkCover Authority of New South Wales
text: The agency formed part of the Safety, Return to Work and Support Division established pursuant to the "Safety, Return to Work and Support Board Act, 2012" (NSW) .

title: Virginia State Board of Censors
text: The Virginia State Board of Censors was a government agency formed on August 1, 1922 for the purpose of reviewing and licensing films for approval to be screened in the state of Virginia.

title: Virginia State Board of Censors
text: During the agency's existence its members examined over 52,000 films, over 2,000 of which required edits before approval was given; and another 157 films were rejected entirely, of which only 38 won subsequent approval.

title: Virginia State Board of Censors
text: The board disbanded in 1968 following a series of U.S. Supreme Court rulings which overturned censorship statutes across the country.

title: Central–Wan Chai Bypass
text: The Central–Wan Chai Bypass is a four-kilometre trunk road, currently under construction, running between Sheung Wan and Fortress Hill on Hong Kong Island.

title: Central–Wan Chai Bypass
text: The original design consists of a 2.3 km dual three-lane tunnel running under new reclamation areas which will be provided by Central and Wan Chai Reclamation project, and also connections to Connaught Road West flyover and Island Eastern Corridor.

title: Central–Wan Chai Bypass
text: When completed, it will substitute Connaught Road Central, Harcourt Road, Gloucester Road and Victoria Park Road to be part of Route 4.

title: Wan Chai District Council
text: Wan Chai District Council () is the district council for the Wan Chai District in Hong Kong.

title: Wan Chai District Council
text: It is one of 18 district councils.

title: Wan Chai District Council
text: Wan Chai District currently consists of 13 members, of which the district is divided into 13 constituencies, electing a total of 13 members.

title: Wan Chai District Council
text: The latest election was held on 22 November 2015.

title: Wan Chai
text: Wan Chai ( ) is a metropolitan area situated at the western part of the Wan Chai District on the northern shore of Hong Kong Island, in Hong Kong.

title: Wan Chai
text: Its other boundaries are Canal Road to the east, Arsenal Street to the west and Bowen Road to the south.

title: Wan Chai
text: The area north of Gloucester Road is often referred to as Wan Chai North.

title: Wan Chai
text: Wan Chai is one of the busiest commercial areas in Hong Kong with offices of many small and medium-sized companies.

title: Wan Chai
text: Wan Chai North features office towers, parks, hotels and an international conference and exhibition centre.

title: Wan Chai
text: As one of the first areas developed in Hong Kong, the locale is densely populated yet with noticeable residential zones facing urban decay.

title: Wan Chai
text: Arousing considerable public concern, the government has undertaken several urban renewal projects in recent years.

title: Wan Chai
text: There are many unique landmarks and skyscrapers within the area, most notably the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre (HKCEC), Central Plaza and Hopewell Centre.

title: Wan Chai Cargo Handling Basin
text: The Wan Chai Cargo Handling Basin () is situated in Wan Chai, Hong Kong Island, Hong Kong.

title: Wan Chai Cargo Handling Basin
text: A prime site along Victoria Harbour, it is adjacent to the Wan Chai Sports Ground and located between the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre and the Royal Hong Kong Yacht Club.

title: Wan Chai Cargo Handling Basin
text: The site has been earmarked under the Central and Wan Chai Reclamation project for the construction of a highway linking Central with Causeway Bay, aimed at easing traffic congestion along the northern coast of Hong Kong Island.

title: Central Harbourfront
text: The Central Harbourfront is a waterfront site in Central, Hong Kong.

title: Central Harbourfront
text: It is the result of Central and Wan Chai Reclamation, and it sits to the east of ifc skyscraper.

title: International Finance Center Seoul
text: International Finance Centre Seoul(서울국제금융센터), commonly known IFC Seoul(아이 에프 시 서울), is a mixed-use integrated commercial development in Seoul, South Korea.

title: International Finance Center Seoul
text: It is located in Yeouido-dong, Yeongdeungpo-gu, Seoul, South Korea.

title: International Finance Center Seoul
text: The IFC project is one of the first large-scale developments in Korea, led by an international consortium.

title: International Finance Center Seoul
text: It was officially launched in 2005, and is part of Seoul Metropolitan Government's plan to rejuvenate the Yeouido area as a regional financial hub.

title: Central Plaza (Hong Kong)
text: Central Plaza is a 78-storey, 374 m skyscraper completed in August 1992 at 18 Harbour Road, in Wan Chai on Hong Kong Island in Hong Kong.

title: Central Plaza (Hong Kong)
text: It is the third tallest tower in the city after 2 International Finance Centre in Central and the ICC in West Kowloon.

title: Central Plaza (Hong Kong)
text: It was the tallest building in Asia from 1992 to 1996, until the Shun Hing Square in neighbouring Shenzhen was built.

title: Central Plaza (Hong Kong)
text: Central Plaza surpassed the Bank of China Tower as the tallest building in Hong Kong until the completion of 2 IFC.

title: International Finance Centre (Hong Kong)
text: The International Finance Centre (abbr.

title: International Finance Centre (Hong Kong)
text: IFC, branded as "ifc") is a skyscraper and an integrated commercial development on the waterfront of Hong Kong's Central District.

title: Lung Wo Road
text: Lung Wo Road (Chinese:龍和道) is a road between Central and Wan Chai, Hong Kong.

title: Lung Wo Road
text: It is constructed in three phases as part of the Central and Wan Chai Reclamation.

title: Lung Wo Road
text: The first two phases are completed by 2010 and 2011 respectively and the third is expected to be completed in 2017.

title: Wan Chai Sports Ground
text: Wan Chai Sports Ground () is a stadium in Wan Chai North, Hong Kong Island, Hong Kong, with a seating capacity of 2,401.

title: Wan Chai Sports Ground
text: It is a government-run sports ground primarily used by local schools for sports days and other athletic activities.

title: Wan Chai Sports Ground
text: Situated by the Victoria Harbour, it is at a convenient location next to Hong Kong's Central business district, Wan Chai, and the shopping district of Causeway Bay.

title: White Crosses
text: White Crosses (in German: "Weiße Kreuze") is a memorial for those who died during the Cold War at the Berlin Wall.

title: White Crosses
text: It is located at the shore of the river Spree in Berlin next to the Reichstag building, which houses the German parliament.

title: White Crosses
text: Established by the private group "Berliner Bürger-Verein" on the 10th anniversary of the Berlin Wall in 1971 it was first located east of the Reichstag on a fence directly in front of the wall.

title: White Crosses
text: After the German reunification in 1990 it kept its location until construction of the new government buildings next to the Reichstag was started at the end of that century – Berlin was chosen to be the new capital of Germany.

title: Reichstag building
text: The Reichstag (German: "Reichstagsgebäude" ] ; officially: "Deutscher Bundestag - Plenarbereich Reichstagsgebäude" ] ) is a historic edifice in Berlin, Germany, constructed to house the Imperial Diet (German: "Reichstag"), of the German Empire.

title: Reichstag building
text: It was opened in 1894 and housed the Diet until 1933, when it was severely damaged after being set on fire.

title: Reichstag building
text: After World War II, the building fell into disuse; the parliament of the German Democratic Republic (the "Volkskammer") met in the "Palast der Republik" in East Berlin, while the parliament of the Federal Republic of Germany (the "Bundestag") met in the "Bundeshaus" in Bonn.

title: Paul Wallot
text: Paul Wallot (26 June 1841 Oppenheim am Rhein – 10 August 1912 Bad Schwalbach) was a German architect of Huguenot descent, best known for designing the Reichstag building in Berlin, erected between 1884 and 1894.

title: Paul Wallot
text: He also built the adjacent Palace of the President of the Reichstag, finished in 1904, and the former Saxon "Ständehaus" state diet building of 1906 at Brühl's Terrace in Dresden.

title: Politics of Berlin
text: Berlin is a city-state and the capital of the Federal Republic of Germany.

title: Politics of Berlin
text: The President of Germany, whose functions are primarily ceremonial under the German constitution, has his official residence in Schloss Bellevue.

title: Politics of Berlin
text: Berlin is the seat of the German executive, housed in the Chancellery (the "Bundeskanzleramt").

title: Politics of Berlin
text: Facing the Chancellery is the Bundestag, the German Parliament, housed in the renovated Reichstag building since the government's move to Berlin in 1998.

title: Politics of Berlin
text: The Bundesrat ("federal council", functioning as an upper house) represents the Federal States ("Bundesländer") of Germany and has its seat at the former Prussian House of Lords.

title: Marinus van der Lubbe
text: Marinus (Rinus) van der Lubbe (13 January 1909 – 10 January 1934) was a Dutch council communist tried, convicted and executed for setting fire to the German Reichstag building on 27 February 1933, an event known as the Reichstag fire.

title: Kroll Opera House
text: The Kroll Opera House (German: "Krolloper, Kroll-Oper" ) was an opera building in Berlin, Germany, located in the central Tiergarten district on the western edge of the "Königsplatz" square (today "Platz der Republik"), facing the Reichstag building.

title: Kroll Opera House
text: It was built in 1844 as an entertainment venue for the restaurant owner Joseph Kroll.

title: Kroll Opera House
text: During its eventful history it was redeveloped as an opera house in 1851 and was used by various owners and directors for opera, operetta and drama.

title: Kroll Opera House
text: It was later operated by the Prussian state opera and drama companies and served as the assembly hall of the German Reichstag parliament from 1933 until 1942.

title: Kroll Opera House
text: On 19 July 1940, the opera house was used to host the 1940 Field Marshal Ceremony.

title: Kroll Opera House
text: Severely damaged by bombing and the Battle of Berlin in World War II, it was finally demolished in 1951.

title: Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag
text: The Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag is a memorial in Berlin, Germany.

title: Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag
text: The memorial is located in front of the Reichstag building, and commemorates the 96 members of the parliament who died unnaturally between 1933 and 1945 (1948).

title: Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag
text: The idea of creating the monument started in the 1980s, and the memorial was erected in September 1992.

title: Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag
text: It was designed by Dieter Appelt, Klaus W. Eisenlohr, Justus Müller and Christian Zwirner.

title: Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag
text: The memorial is made of 96 cast iron plates, with the names, birth and death dates and places engraved on the edges.

title: Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag
text: It has been designed so that it can be extended if new names are discovered in the future.

title: Reichstag fire
text: The Reichstag fire (German: "Reichstagsbrand" , ) was an arson attack on the Reichstag building (home of the German parliament) in Berlin on 27 February 1933, just one month after Adolf Hitler had been sworn in as Chancellor of Germany.

title: Reichstag fire
text: The Nazis stated that Marinus van der Lubbe, a Dutch council communist, was found near the building.

title: Reichstag fire
text: The Nazis publicly blamed the fire on communist agitators in general, although in a German court in 1933, it was decided that Van Der Lubbe had acted alone, as he claimed to have done.

title: Reichstag fire
text: After the fire, the Reichstag Fire Decree was passed.

title: Reichstag fire
text: The fire was used as evidence by the Nazi Party that communists were plotting against the German government.

title: Reichstag fire
text: The event is seen as pivotal in the establishment of Nazi Germany.

title: Bundestag (Berlin U-Bahn)
text: Bundestag is a Berlin U-Bahn station located on the U55 .

title: Bundestag (Berlin U-Bahn)
text: The name of this station was changed in April 2006 from Reichstag to Bundestag after deputations from the Bundestag which sits in the Reichstag building.

title: Mikhail Minin
text: Mikhail Petrovich Minin (Russian: Михаил Петрович Минин ) (July 29, 1922 – January 10, 2008) was a Russian Soviet soldier who was the first to enter the Reichstag building on April 30, 1945 during the Battle of Berlin, and the first soldier to mount the flag on the Reichstag building at 10:40 pm.

title: Gorgeous George (album)
text: Gorgeous George is the third solo studio album by Scottish musician Edwyn Collins.

title: Gorgeous George (album)
text: The album was recorded at New River in London, with Collins acting as the producer.

title: I'm Not Following You
text: I'm Not Following You is an album by Scottish musician Edwyn Collins released in 1997.

title: Doctor Syntax (album)
text: Doctor Syntax is an album by Scottish musician Edwyn Collins.

title: Hellbent on Compromise
text: Hellbent on Compromise is an album by a Scottish musician Edwyn Collins.

title: Paul Quinn (singer)
text: Paul Walter Quinn (born 1959) is a Scottish musician who was the lead singer of cult 1980s band Bourgie Bourgie, and also released records with Jazzateers, Vince Clarke and Edwyn Collins and sang on an early track by the French Impressionists.

title: A Casual Introduction 1981/2001
text: A Casual Introduction 1981/2001 is an album by Scottish musician Edwyn Collins.

title: A Casual Introduction 1981/2001
text: It is a collection of both his solo work and also work of Orange Juice, the band he fronted from 1979 to the mid-80s.

title: Hope and Despair
text: Hope and Despair is the debut solo album by Scottish musician Edwyn Collins.

title: Edwyn Collins
text: Edwyn Stephen Collins (born 23 August 1959) is a Scottish musician, producer and record label owner from Edinburgh, Scotland.

title: Edwyn Collins
text: Collins was the lead singer for the 1980s post-punk band Orange Juice, which he co-founded.

title: Edwyn Collins
text: Following the group's split in 1985, Collins started a solo career.

title: Edwyn Collins
text: His 1994 single "A Girl Like You" was a worldwide hit.

title: Orange Juice (band)
text: Orange Juice was a Scottish post-punk band founded in the Glasgow suburb of Bearsden as the Nu-Sonics in 1976.

title: Orange Juice (band)
text: Edwyn Collins formed the Nu-Sonics (named after a cheap brand of guitar) with his school-mate Alan Duncan and was subsequently joined by James Kirk and Steven Daly, who left a band called The Machetes.

title: Orange Juice (band)
text: The band became Orange Juice in 1979.

title: Orange Juice (band)
text: They are best known for the hit "Rip It Up", which reached number 8 on the UK Singles Chart in February 1983, the band's only UK Top 40 hit.

title: Jimmie Ross
text: Jimmie Ross is an American rock guitarist and vocalist who is best known for being a member of Pittsburgh band the Jaggerz, known for their 1970 hit "The Rapper".

title: Jimmie Ross
text: During the band's initial existence of 1965-1976, the bassist shared the duties of lead vocalist with guitarist Donnie Iris.

title: Jimmie Ross
text: By the time the Jaggerz regrouped in 1989, Iris was well into his solo career, and Ross became the sole lead vocalist and remained bassist.

title: Jimmie Ross
text: He continues to hold both positions today.

title: Erie Bluffs State Park
text: Erie Bluffs State Park is a 587 acre Pennsylvania state park in Girard and Springfield Townships, Erie County, Pennsylvania in the United States.

title: Erie Bluffs State Park
text: The park is the largest undeveloped stretch of land overlooking Lake Erie in Pennsylvania.

title: Erie Bluffs State Park
text: Erie Bluffs State Park is just north of Pennsylvania Route 5 near Lake City and 12 mi west of Erie.

title: Erie Bluffs State Park
text: It is one of Pennsylvania's newest state parks.

title: Poe Valley State Park
text: Poe Valley State Park is a 620 acre Pennsylvania state park in Penn Township, Centre County, Pennsylvania in the United States.

title: Poe Valley State Park
text: The park is surrounded by Bald Eagle State Forest.

title: Poe Valley State Park
text: Poe Paddy State Park is 4 mi to the east.

title: Poe Valley State Park
text: The forests of the park surround the 25 acre Poe Lake.

title: Poe Valley State Park
text: Poe Valley State Park is in isolated Poe Valley which lies between Potters Mills on U.S. Route 322 and Millheim on Pennsylvania Route 45.

title: Poe Valley State Park
text: The park was closed during the 2008 and 2009 season while the lake was drained for dam repairs and the park facilities were upgraded.

title: Presque Isle State Park
text: Presque Isle State Park is a 3112 acre Pennsylvania state park on an arching, sandy peninsula that juts into Lake Erie, 4 mi west of the city of Erie, in Millcreek Township, Erie County, Pennsylvania, in the United States.

title: Presque Isle State Park
text: The peninsula sweeps northeastward, surrounding Presque Isle Bay along the park's southern coast.

title: Presque Isle State Park
text: It has 13 mi of roads, 21 mi of recreational trails, 13 beaches for swimming, and a marina.

title: Presque Isle State Park
text: Popular activities at the park include swimming, boating, hiking, biking, and birdwatching.

title: Sinnemahoning State Park
text: Sinnemahoning State Park is a 1910 acre Pennsylvania state park in Grove Township, Cameron County and Wharton Township, Potter County, Pennsylvania in the United States.

title: Sinnemahoning State Park
text: The park is surrounded by Elk State Forest and is mountainous with deep valleys.
